Gov. Parris N. Glendening is seriously considering vetoing legislation that would make Maryland the first state to require that all public school students take a gun safety class.
The governor has been besieged with calls from teachers troubled by the measure's
continuation:
potential impact on their classrooms, but he hasn't made up his mind yet.
"I'm still reviewing it," he said in an interview Friday. "I want to make sure there's no unintended consequences."
The bill (HB 709) would mandate that every student in grades K-12 take a three-hour course on how to safely handle firearms and other weapons. It was approved by the House of Delegates last week and now goes to the Senate for consideration.
Supporters say the law is needed to help prevent future mass shootings like the one at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., where 17 people were killed Feb. 14.
But opponents say the requirement could have a chilling effect on free speech and academic freedom. The National Rifle Association has threatened to sue if the law is signed into law.
Glendening, a Republican who took office in January after serving two terms as lieutenant governor under former Democratic Gov. Martin O'Malley, has not indicated whether he will sign the bill or veto it.
"We're going to be looking at it very carefully," he said. "There are a lot of good reasons why we should do this, and there are a lot of

input: If you're of a paranoid disposition, you're probably warning yourself right now that this article runs the risk of discussing something gruesome, such as sausage made of puppies. "Oh my god," you might be thinking, "is that what they do with
continuation:
puppies in China?"

The answer is no. It's not, and it shouldn't be. But there are some things we need to talk about before we get too far down the rabbit hole. For one thing, it's important to note that these animals aren't being killed for their meat. They're being killed for their skins, which are used to make products like clothing, bedding, and furniture.

Advertisement

This isn't the first time I've written about the fur trade, but I think it's worth revisiting it again. The fur trade has been around for thousands of years. In fact, it predates human civilization by tens of thousands of years. Humans have been killing other animals for their fur since at least the Stone Age, when people were hunting mammoths and bison.

Fur was a valuable commodity in ancient times because it had a lot of usesit could be used to make clothing, tools, weapons, jewelry, and even medicine. As technology advanced, so did the demand for fur. People started making clothes out of it, and then later on, they began using it as an insulator. Fur coats became popular in the early 20th century, and by the

input: At its AppsWorld developer conference, in front of an estimated 10,000 customers and developers, Oracle president Chuck Philips harped on the shows theme of software integration. In his opening keynote, Phillips noted that interoperability (getting software to
continuation:
work with each other) is one of the biggest challenges facing IT today.

Were going to talk about how were going to make it easier for you to do your job, he said. Im going to talk about how were going to make it easier for you to do your job.

He didnt go into much detail, but Phillips did say that the company will be releasing a new set of APIs (application programming interfaces) in the second half of this year. The APIs are designed to help developers build applications that can interact with each other more easily.

Phillips also talked up Oracles cloud-based application development platform (ADP), which lets developers create apps without having to write code. He said that ADP has already been used by more than 100,000 people around the world.

We want to make it easy for you to get started, Phillips said. Its not just about getting started; its about making it easy for you to stay there. Weve got a lot of great things coming down the pike

input:
A woman sucker punched and stabbed on the subway says the attack was motivated by hate. Wale Aliyu reports.
A woman was punched and stabbed when she got off the subway in Brooklyn by a man yelling racially charged words, her family and
continuation:
law enforcement sources told The New York Times.
The incident occurred at around 6:45 p.m. Tuesday on the No. 2 train at Grand Concourse station in Bedford-Stuyvesant, police said.
According to witnesses, the attacker yelled get out of my country as he approached the victim, who was wearing a headscarf, and punched her in the face several times before stabbing her once in the back.
The assailant then ran away with the victims cell phone, which had been left behind, according to law enforcement sources.
The victim was taken to Kings County Hospital, where she was treated for non-life-threatening injuries. Her condition was not immediately known.
Police are looking for the attacker, described as a black man in his late 20s or early 30s. He is about 5 feet 8 inches tall and weighs between 140 and 160 pounds. He was last seen wearing a blue hooded sweatshirt, black sweatpants and white sneakers.

input: Inside Rebel-Held Syria NPR's Kelly McEvers spent a week with anti-government rebels knows as the Free Syrian Army. The government holds the country's cities, but the rebels control considerable territory in rural area near the Turkish border.
continuation:
KELLY MCEVERS, HOST:

This is MORNING EDITION from NPR News. Good morning. I'm Kelly McEvers.

RENEE MONTAGNE, HOST:

And I'm Renee Montagne.

We're joined now by NPR's Kelly McEvers, who has been reporting on the conflict in Syria for more than two years. And she joins us from the rebel-held town of Saraqeb in the northern province of Idlib.

Welcome to the program. How are you doing?

KELLY MCEVERS, BYLINE: Hi, Renee.

MONTAGNE: So what was your first impression of this place when you arrived?

MCEVERS: Well, it's a very small town. It's only about 20,000 people, and there's not much infrastructure here at all. You have a few schools, a few hospitals, a couple of bakeries, a few grocery stores, and that's about it.

You know, we were walking through the streets, and there was no electricity or running water. We saw a lot of abandoned cars. There was a lot of trash everywhere.

input:
Today's Millennials could be tomorrow's very sweaty retirees thanks to temperatures and humidity levels that are rising so fast that, by the end of this century, simply going outside could be deadly.
The study's alarming findings put into sharp perspective not just what
continuation:
climate change is doing to our planet, but also how we can do something about it.
In a new paper published in the journal Climatic Change, researchers at the University of Exeter have found that the average global temperature has already risen by 1.1 degrees Celsius since pre-industrial times, and will likely continue to rise for the next 100 years or more.
This means that, if we don't start taking action now, the world will be much hotter than it was before the industrial revolution.
"Climate change is one of the biggest challenges facing humanity," said co-author Dr. Richard Betts from the University of Exeter's Department of Geography. "We need to take urgent action to reduce carbon emissions to limit global warming to 1.5C above pre-industrial levels."
To get a sense of just how bad things are getting, consider these numbers: In the U.S., the average summer heat wave is expected to get worse over the next few decades, according to a recent report from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).
According to the report, the number of heat waves in the U.S. is expected to increase by up to 50 percent between now and 2050.

input:
Police recruits should try to answer every question on a screening exam.
2 What Are Some Disqualifications for Getting a Job With a Police Department?
For police recruits, the psychological evaluation process represents one of the last hurdles to getting hired. The
continuation:
test is designed to weed out people who are likely to commit crimes or be troublemakers, and it's not uncommon for candidates to fail.
But there are some disqualifications that aren't so obvious. For example, if you have a history of mental illness, you may be disqualified from joining the force. Or you might be disqualified if you've been arrested multiple times in the past five years, or if your criminal record includes convictions for driving under the influence of drugs or alcohol, domestic violence, or sexual assault.
If you're looking to get a job with a law enforcement agency, here's what you need to know before you take the test.
How do I prepare for the test?
Before taking the test, you'll want to make sure you have all the necessary materials. You'll need to fill out an application, which will include information about your background, education, and employment history. You'll also need to bring copies of your driver's license, birth certificate, and Social Security card. If you don't have any of those documents, you can still apply, but you won't be considered.
You'll also need to submit a copy of your medical records, such as a doctor's note or a letter from

input: In this file photo from May 4, 2018, a pipe and drum corps marches past the Kansas Law Enforcement Memorial during the 36th annual memorial service honoring peace officers who have been killed in the line of duty. The memorial, which is now nearly full
continuation:
, was originally built to honor law enforcement officers who died while on duty. (AP Photo/Charlie Riedel, File)

KANSAS CITY, Mo. (AP)  A Kansas City-area high school marching band will perform at next months inauguration of President-elect Donald Trump, an arrangement that has drawn criticism from some students and parents.

The Missouri State High School Activities Association said Friday that the Spirit of America Marching Band will perform at Trumps Jan. 20 swearing-in ceremony at the U.S. Capitol.

The groups website says it will be performing the National Anthem and other patriotic songs.

ADVERTISEMENT

Its not clear how many members of the band are expected to attend the event.

Some students and parents say they dont want their children to take part in the performance.

Sen. Tom Bakk will remain the DFL leader, but this time in the minority.
Sen. Paul Gazelka was elected by his Republican colleagues Thursday to be the new majority leader of the Minnesota Senate.
Gazelka will join
continuation:
Sen. Karin Housley, R-St. Paul, as Democrats' top two leaders when the Legislature reconvenes in January.
Bakk, a St. Paul Democrat, has served as Senate president pro tempore since 2015 and is the longest-serving senator in state history.
He announced earlier this month that he would not seek re-election next year.
"It's been an honor to serve my fellow Minnesotans for more than 30 years," Bakk said in a news release. "I'm proud of the work we've done together and look forward to working with our colleagues on both sides of the aisle to build on the progress we've made over the last four years."
Gazelka, a former state House member from Bloomington, was first elected to the Senate in 2006. He has served as Senate majority leader since 2013.
"The people of Minnesota have entrusted me with the responsibility of leading the Senate," Gazelka said in a news release. Defensive back K'Waun Williams, shown after making a big play for the Pitt Panthers last season, has signed with the Cleveland Browns.
CLEVELAND, Ohio -- The Browns continue to add to their cornerback pile.
On Tuesday,
continuation:
the team announced that it had signed free-agent defensive back K'Waun Williams, who was released by the Pittsburgh Steelers earlier this month.
Williams played in all 16 games for the Steelers last season, starting five of them. He recorded three passes defensed, two interceptions and one forced fumble.
The 6-foot-2, 190-pound Williams originally entered the NFL as an undrafted free agent out of Texas A&M in 2018.
He spent his rookie season on the Steelers practice squad before being promoted to the 53-man roster during training camp in 2019.
In 2020, Williams appeared in seven games for the Steelers, recording six tackles and one pass defensed. He also started one game at strong safety.
Browns head coach Kevin Stefanski is familiar with Williams from his time with the Minnesota Vikings.
"We are excited to have him join our football team," Stefanski said in a statement. "His versatility will be a great asset to our defense."
Stefanski added: "I know he's been working hard and we're looking forward to seeing what he can do for us."
Williams joins a group of cornerbacks that includes Denzel Ward, Greedy Williams, Andrew Sendejo

input:
As Athens goes to the polls, has the British left fallen out of love with the EU?
In 1874, Karl Marx had an imaginary conversation with Mikhail Bakunin. Nowadays, they would just have had a Twitter spat, but back then
continuation:
Marx and Bakunin were talking about Britain's relationship with the European Union (EU).
"What do you think?" Marx asked his friend. "Should we join the EU or not?"
Bakunin replied that he thought it was a good idea, but added: "I don't know if we will be able to stay in it."
The exchange took place at a time when Britain was on the verge of joining the European Economic Community (EEC)  the forerunner of the European Union. It was the first time Marx had spoken to someone who did not share his views on the future of Europe.
It is now more than 50 years since Marx and Bakunin met. The UK is due to leave the EU on 31 October, and the country's political landscape has changed dramatically over the past few decades.
In the early 1970s, the Labour Party led by Clement Attlee won a landslide victory in the general election. In 1979, Margaret Thatcher became prime minister for the first time. She promised to cut taxes and increase spending on public services such as the National Health Service (NHS) and social housing.
These policies were popular with the British people, who saw them as a way to improve their standard of

input: NOVOLUHANSKE, Ukraine (Reuters) - Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko thought he could rely for his re-election in part on the votes of soldiers who have spent years fighting pro-Russian separatists. But a visit to the frontline
continuation:
this week has shown him that they are not so easy to win over.

Ukrainian servicemen stand guard at a checkpoint near Novoluhanske in the Donetsk region, Ukraine July 25, 2018. REUTERS/Valentyn Ogirenko

Poroshenkos campaign was built on promises to improve living standards and fight corruption, but the country remains deeply divided between those who want closer ties with the European Union and others who want to stay in Russias orbit.

His trip to the frontlines in eastern Ukraine, where government forces have been battling Russian-backed separatists since April 2014, showed how difficult it can be to convince people to give up their guns.

I dont know if I will be able to convince them to vote for me, Poroshenko told reporters after a meeting with troops in the city of Novoazovsk. We need to work on this.

Poroshenko is facing off against Volodymyr Zelenskiy, the comedian who won a landslide victory in a presidential election last month.

input: From the house of ZURB, creators of such apps as Bounce, Notable, Reel and Strike, comes another Web app called Spur. Its a free app that aims to help Web designers return to basics and ensure that they
continuation:
dont get lost in all the bells and whistles of modern web design.

Spur lets you see what your designs would look like if they were printed out on paper. You can use it to make mockups or even print them out for real.

You can also add text, images, links, and other elements to your designs.

The app is currently available for iOS and Android, but will be coming soon to Windows Phone.

input: What were the politics of abortion like in this country before Roe v. Wade? Different than what I thought in a couple of important ways, Ive learned from a new book, Before Roe v. Wade, by Linda Greenhouse and Rev
continuation:
. William Barber II.

Greenhouse is an associate professor of history at Princeton University, where she teaches courses on U.S. womens history. She has written several books, including The Feminine Mystique, which was made into a movie starring Reese Witherspoon and Jennifer Aniston.

Barber is the president of the North Carolina chapter of the NAACP, and he leads the Moral Monday protests that have been taking place in Raleigh for more than two years. He also serves as pastor of First Baptist Church of Winston-Salem, one of the largest African-American congregations in the state.

Before Roe v. Wade: A History of Abortion in America (Penguin Random House; $27.95) tells the story of the fight to end abortion in the United States, from its beginnings in the 19th century until the Supreme Court ruling in 1973 that legalized it.

The book is divided into three parts. The first part covers the period from the beginning of the 19th century to the Civil War. The second deals with the period from the Civil War through World War II. The third part focuses on the period after the war.

Paparazzi who took photographs of Princess Diana dying in a car wreck stopped police from getting to the scene, her inquest heard today.
Eyewitness Clifford Goorovadoo said: "It is true that when the first police officers
continuation:
arrived they were not allowed to get close to the car because it was on fire.
"They had to wait for an ambulance to arrive and then they were allowed to go closer."
The crash happened at around 8pm on August 31, 1997, in Paris' Champs-Elysees boulevard near the Arc de Triomphe.
Diana, 36, was travelling with Dodi Al Fayed, 42, and their chauffeur Henri Paul in a Jaguar XK120 when the car crashed into a wall.
Mr Goorovadoo told the hearing he saw the car's rear end hit a concrete pillar and burst into flames.
He added: "I could see smoke coming out of the back of the car.
"When I looked up there was a lot of smoke coming out of the back of the car.
"There was a lot of smoke coming out of the back of the car.
"It was a big black cloud of smoke coming out of the back of the car.

Cadillac Fairview Corp. Ltd. is the latest Canadian real estate giant to make a concerted push into technology investing by backing a new $150-million venture-capital fund
continuation:
that will invest in companies developing artificial intelligence and machine learning technologies.
In a statement Tuesday, Cadillac Fairview said it has invested $50 million of its own money in the fund, which was launched in partnership with Silicon Valley venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz.
Story continues below advertisement
"We believe this is an exciting time to be investing in Canada's tech sector," said Cadillac Fairview president and chief executive officer Lou Pacheco. "We're excited about the potential for AI and ML to transform how we live, work and play in the future."
Andreessen Horowitz CEO Marc Benioff said the fund will focus on early-stage investments in companies that are working to build tools and systems that can help businesses improve their decision-making processes and reduce costs.
Benioff added that the fund will also seek to invest in companies that have already been built but haven't yet gone public.
Cadillac Fairview is not the first major Canadian real estate company to get involved in technology investing. In January, Brookfield Asset Management Inc. announced it had set up a $1-billion venture capital fund focused on artificial intelligence, machine learning and data science.

input: Lauren Noland has a love for exotic food. The Eagle River, Alaska native attributes her love of adventurous things to some of the wild meats available growing up, including her favorite dish, caribou sausage lasagna. A veteran herself, and
continuation:
one who served in the U.S. Armys 101st Airborne Division, she now works as a military nutritionist with the Department of Veterans Affairs.

She is also the author of the cookbook The Caribou Cookbook (HarperCollins). In this interview, she talks about how she came to write the book, what it was like to serve in Iraq, and why she believes that eating meat can be good for your health.

Q: What inspired you to write The Caribou Cookbook?

A: I have always loved cooking, but when I moved to Alaska, I realized that there were so many different kinds of foods that could be made from local ingredients. I wanted to share those recipes with others.

Q: How long did it take you to write the book?

A: It took me about two years to write the book. I worked on it every day while I was working at the VA.

Q: Did you find it hard to keep track of everything?

A: Yes, I found it very difficult to keep track of all of the recipes. I kept a notebook next to my computer

input: DES MOINES, Iowa (AP)  Authorities apprehended a man Wednesday suspected in the early morning killings of two Des Moines area police officers who were shot to death while sitting in their patrol cars in what authorities described as separate ambush-style attacks.
continuation:
Des Moines Police Chief Paul Parizek said during a news conference that the suspect was taken into custody without incident at his home and is being held on first-degree murder charges. He did not release any other details about the suspects identity or where he was arrested.

Parizek said the suspect was identified after an extensive investigation involving multiple law enforcement agencies, including the FBI and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives.

We believe this individual is responsible for these murders, Parizek said.

The shooting happened shortly before 2:30 a.m. Tuesday when the officers responded to a call about a suspicious person near the intersection of North 10th Street and West Locust Avenue in Des Moines. The officers found two people with gunshot wounds and took them to a local hospital, where they later died from their injuries.

Police have not released the names or ages of the officers but said they were both members of the Des Moines Police Departments Special Response Team and had been assigned to the citys East Precinct.

This is a very difficult time for our entire community, Parizek said.

input:
Thermal emission from erupting volcanoes on the Jupiter's moon Io. A logarithmic scale is used to classify volcanoes on the basis of thermal emission; the larger the spot, the larger the thermal emission.
A new map of
continuation:
volcanic activity on Io has been created by scientists using data from NASAs Galileo spacecraft, which was launched in 1997 and has since orbited Jupiter for more than 13 years. The map reveals a vast array of volcanoes on Io, including some that have not been seen before.
Io is the second-largest planet in our solar system after Earth. It orbits Jupiter at a distance of about 1,200 miles (2,000 kilometers), making it one of the most distant planets in the Solar System. Scientists believe that Io may be an active world, as its surface is covered with numerous craters that were formed by volcanic eruptions. However, there are still many unknowns about Ios geology, such as how much lava flows beneath the surface.
To better understand these mysteries, researchers analyzed data collected by NASAs Galileo spacecraft between 1999 and 2005. The team then used computer models to estimate the amount of volcanic activity on Io over the past few thousand years. They found that volcanic activity increased dramatically during the last ice age, around 12,000 years ago.
Its very difficult to predict what will happen next, said study co-author Michael Gazzaniga

input:
Hourly workers aren't the only ones who have to track hours worked.
2 What if a Salaried Employee Works More Than 40 Hours?
Ask two workers if they prefer a salary or hourly wage, you will likely get two different answers
continuation:
. But what if one of them works more than 40 hours a week? How does that impact their time off?
The answer is complicated and depends on how many hours the worker actually works each week. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS), salaried employees work an average of 37.5 hours per week. That's about the same as non-salaried employees.
But there are some differences between salaried and hourly employees. For instance, salaried employees tend to work longer hours because they are compensated for every hour they work. In other words, they don't get paid for every minute they spend working.
On the other hand, hourly workers do not receive any compensation for every hour they work. This means that they can be paid for every hour they work even if they work less than 40 hours in a given week.
In fact, according to a recent study by the National Employment Law Project (NELP) and the National Association of State Workforce Agencies (NASWA), salaried workers are more likely than hourly workers to work more than 40 hours in a week.
What Does It Mean To Be Paid By The Hour?

input:
KINSHASA Democratic Republic of Congo's top court on Monday definitively excluded opposition leader Jean-Pierre Bemba from December's presidential election because of a witness tampering conviction at the International Criminal Court.
KINSHASA Congolese
continuation:
President Joseph Kabila, who has been in power since 2001 and is due to step down after 18 years in office next year, was barred from standing for re-election by an electoral commission decision last week.
The Constitutional Court ruled that Bemba could not be allowed to run because he had been found guilty of crimes against humanity by the Hague-based ICC, which is investigating alleged atrocities committed during the country's civil war that ended in 2003.
"We have decided to disqualify Jean-Pierre Bemba from running for president," Chief Justice Felix Tshisekedi told reporters. "He will no longer be able to take part in the elections."

input: The dominant position that Microsoft software occupies on the desktop has long been a major source of competitive advantage to Microsoft. Not only does it ensure that users of Microsoft software are familiar with the look and feel of the Microsoft interface but it also has provided a launch
continuation:
pad for new products, such as Internet Explorer.

Microsoft is not alone in its dominance of the desktop operating system market. Apple's Mac OS X remains the most popular desktop operating system in the United States, followed by Windows XP and Linux.

But according to research firm Gartner, which recently released its Worldwide Quarterly Desktop Operating System Tracker (WQDSOT) report, Microsoft's share of the desktop operating system market will decline over the next five years.

Gartner predicts that Microsoft will account for less than half of the worldwide desktop operating system market by 2012, down from more than two-thirds in 2007.

In fact, Gartner predicts that the worldwide desktop operating system market will be dominated by three different operating systems -- Apple's iOS, Google's Android, and Microsoft's Windows 8 -- by 2012.

"This is an important shift," said Michael Ovitz, principal analyst at Gartner. "We've seen this before. In the late 1990s and early 2000s, there was a lot of talk about how Microsoft would dominate the personal computer market. It never materialized. The same thing is happening now."

According to Ovitz, the reasons for the decline

input: Amazon has announced another twist on the Fire TV in the form of the Fire TV Cube. If you imagine the functionality of the Fire TV, combine it with an Echo Dot and add in a bit of universal remote control, you've arrived at the Fire
continuation:
TV Cube.

The Fire TV Cube is Amazon's answer to Google's Chromecast Ultra, which launched earlier this year for $50 less than the Fire TV Stick 4K. It comes with Alexa built-in, so you can use voice commands to stream content from your phone, tablet, or computer, as well as play music, make video calls, and more. It also includes a USB port for charging other devices like phones, tablets, and computers.

You'll be able to purchase the Fire TV Cube for $99 when it goes on sale later this month. You can pre-order it right now if you want to get a head start on the holiday shopping season.

This is a huge step forward in our countrys history, said U.S. Rep. Jared Polis (D-Colo.), who introduced the Marijuana Opportunity Reinvestment and Expungement (MORE) Act earlier this year. The legalization of marijuana is long overdue and I am proud to have worked with my colleagues in both chambers to make it happen.

Colorado and Washington were the first two states to legalize marijuana for medical use in 1998. Since then, more than a dozen others have followed suit, including California, Maine, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, Rhode Island, Vermont, and Pennsylvania.

In 2013, the National Conference of State Legislatures reported that at least 30 states had legalized some form of medical marijuana.

We are excited to be one of the first states to legalize adult-use marijuana, said Gov. John Hickenlooper (D), who signed the bill into law on Wednesday. Its been a long time coming and were going to do it right.

input:
Gloucester claimed their second win of the season to impose a third defeat of the fledgling campaign on Wasps.
Stephen Jones put Wasps 3-0 ahead before two Freddie Burns penalties and a converted James Simpson-Daniel try gave the hosts a
continuation:
bonus point victory at Franklins Gardens.
The result leaves Gloucester in sixth place, four points behind leaders Saracens, but with a game in hand.
Wasps, who have now lost five of their last six Premiership matches, remain rooted to the bottom of the table.
Gloucester started the brighter of the two sides and were rewarded after just three minutes when they took the lead for the first time.
Simpson-Daniels dummied his way over from close range following a lineout maul.
It was not long before the visitors had a chance to equalise, however, as Willi Heinz was yellow-carded for an off-the-ball incident.
Jones stepped up to take the resulting penalty and made no mistake as he slotted it into the top corner to give Gloucester a 10-3 lead.
But Wasps hit back almost immediately through replacement scrum-half Matt Kvesic.
Kvesic picked up a loose ball and raced away down the left wing before crossing the whitewash to level the scores at 10-10.

input:
Having joined the ranks of perennial college football bowl participants, Northwestern University also now has joined the ranks of schools at which a coach has the highest annual compensation.
Pat Fitzgerald was credited with more than $2.2 million in compensation during the 2011 calendar
continuation:
year, according to figures released by the NCAA on Wednesday.
Fitzgerald's total includes a base salary of $1.5 million and a $500,000 bonus for winning the Big Ten championship game.
The Wildcats finished 9-4 last season and won their first conference title since 1991.
Northwestern is one of three schools -- along with Florida State and Texas A&M -- that have had multiple coaches earn six-figure salaries over the past five years.
Florida State's Willie Taggart, who took over after Jimbo Fisher left to take the head coaching job at Texas A&M, led the Seminoles to a 10-3 record and an appearance in the Citrus Bowl.
Taggart made $2.6 million in 2011, while Texas A&M's Kevin Sumlin made $2.7 million.
--Field Level Media

input:
Almost three weeks after a primary that wiped out two incumbents, the remaining candidates for Carroll County commissioner are struggling to show voters that they're much different from each other.
Most of the candidates mounted successful primary campaigns by saying they would not be like
continuation:
their predecessors, who have been accused of being too cozy with big business and failing to represent the interests of the people they were elected to serve.
But now that the election is over, it's hard to see how anyone can distinguish themselves from the rest of the field.
"We've got a lot of work to do," said former state Sen. Andy Gipson, who finished third in the race. "I think we all need to look at what we've done and make sure we don't get complacent."
Gipson was one of six candidates vying for three seats on the county's board of commissioners. The top vote-getters will face off in the general election Nov. 5.
In his first run for office, Gipson, a Republican, ran as a moderate who could bridge the gap between Republicans and Democrats. He promised to focus on issues such as education, public safety and economic development.
But he struggled to gain traction in the crowded field. In the end, Gipson came in third place behind incumbent Commissioner John Rafferty and challenger Tim O'Hara.

input: EXCLUSIVE: Imagine Impact is launching its second mentoring program. The program launched last year, to find new writer voices and give them a seat at the table, pairing them with a veteran mentor and giving them a paid eight-week creative boot

camp. This time around, theyre looking for writers who are just getting started in the business.

Theyre looking for talented young people between the ages of 18 and 25 who want to write for television or film. Theyll be paired with an experienced screenwriter who will help them hone their craft and teach them about the ins and outs of the industry.

We know that it can be hard to get your foot in the door if you dont have a lot of experience, but we want to make sure that everyone has the opportunity to break into this industry, said Imagine Impact co-founder and executive producer David Zito. We want to give these talented young people a chance to work with some of the best storytellers in the world.

The deadline for submissions is March 1, 2019. To apply, send a letter of interest and resume to [email protected].

You must be 18 years old or older.

You must be able to commit to a minimum of eight weeks of intensive writing instruction.

input: TUCSON, Ariz. (AP) Arizona was shaky with the ball early, had trouble getting shots to fall from the perimeter. With a roster full of new players and old players in new roles, it was kind of expected.
continuation:
The Wildcats finally got their offense going in the second half and pulled away for an 82-69 victory over Southern California on Thursday night.

We were playing catch-up, Arizona coach Sean Miller said. It wasnt until we started making some shots that we were able to play our brand of basketball. I think thats what weve been trying to do all year. Weve just got to get better at it.

Arizona led by as many as 10 points in the first half before the Trojans went on a 13-0 run to take a 33-31 lead into the locker room. The Wildcats responded with a 19-4 run to take a 41-38 lead into halftime.

I thought they played well, USC coach Andy Enfield said. They did a good job defensively. They made us work for every shot. We didnt have any easy baskets tonight.

After trailing by as many as 11 points in the first half, Arizona scored the final seven points of the half to take a 45-43 lead into the break.

input:
Former Paterson Mayor Pat Kramer reflects on the crises facing Paterson in the wake of Joey Torres' resignation.
In light of the plea agreement made by now former Paterson Mayor Joey Torres, I was asked to reflect on the future of my beloved
continuation:
city and what it will look like when he is no longer a part of it.
I have been thinking about this issue for some time, but never more so than in the last few days. It's hard to put into words what has happened to our city over the past few weeks, but I can say with confidence that we are not where we need to be at this point in our history.
The events of the past few weeks have exposed the deep divisions in our city, and they have also brought us closer together as a community. The outpouring of love and support from our neighbors, friends and family has been nothing short of amazing.
It has been humbling to see how many people have reached out to me to offer their support, whether through phone calls, texts or emails. Many have offered to help me get back on my feet, while others are offering to help me start a new chapter of my life.
There are still many challenges ahead, but I am confident that Paterson will come out of this stronger and more united than ever before.
My heart goes out to all of those who have been affected by this tragedy, especially the families and loved ones of those who were lost. We will always remember them

input: Elaine Tieber and the doctor joke back and forth as he examines the small brown spots on her back. The doctor, Thomas Goleman, brims with a folksy, Southern manner, and Tieber has a sense of humor to match
continuation:
. Im not sure if youve noticed, but I dont have any hair on my head, she says. I think its time for me to shave it all off.

Goleman looks up from his computer screen. Thats funny, he says. I was just thinking about that myself.

Tieber is in her mid-60s and has been balding for more than 30 years. Shed like to get rid of her gray hair, too, but shes reluctant to go under the knife because she doesnt want to look like an old lady. Shes also concerned about the possible side effects of the surgery.

I dont know whats going to happen, she says. Will I be able to walk? Will I be able to talk?

Goleman smiles. Ill bet you wont be able to talk, he says. But we can always try.

input:
QUEENSLAND'S police minster has said the violent home invasions in Murgon last weekend were not targeted.
Mark Ryan said further police resources were immediately deployed to the area over the weekend after the Murgon police prosecutor
continuation:
's office issued a warrant for the arrest of two men accused of breaking into homes and assaulting residents.
The pair, aged 22 and 24, have been charged with aggravated burglary and assault occasioning actual bodily harm.
They are expected to appear in the Brisbane Magistrates Court on Tuesday.
Mr Ryan told The Courier-Mail he was "shocked" when he heard about the incidents.
He said it was "very concerning" that some of the victims had suffered serious injuries, including broken bones and facial lacerations.
Camera Icon Queensland Police Minister Mark Ryan. Picture: News Corp Australia, NCA NewsWire / Gaye Gerard
"It is very concerning," Mr Ryan said.
"We will be looking at this very closely."
Mr Ryan said the state government would provide more funding to local police forces to help them deal with crime.
"We will be providing additional funding to our police forces to ensure they can continue to respond to these types of crimes," he said.
"We want to make sure that we are doing everything we can to keep our communities safe."
Mr Ryan said he hoped the incident would serve as a wake-up call for people to think twice before committing crimes.

input:
Argentina labor's umbrella organization CGT, has organized a strike for Monday to protest the economic reforms being implemented y the administration of president Mauricio Macri's business friendly administration.
Tens of thousands of people have marched on Saturday in central
continuation:
Buenos Aires and other cities across the country to demand an end to the austerity measures that have been imposed by Macri's government since taking office in December 2015.
The protests were largely peaceful, but some protesters clashed with police, who used tear gas and water cannons to disperse them.
CGT said its members would walk off the job from 9 a.m. (0800 GMT) until 1 p.m. (1200 GMT).
Macri's government has cut public spending and raised taxes on gasoline and diesel as part of efforts to reduce Argentina's $100 billion current account deficit.

Julia M. Carpenter, a sophomore in chemical engineering, was found dead in her Random Hall dormitory room early Monday morning. She was 20 years old.
Carpenter was a member of Alpha Chi Sigma (AXE), a professional chemistry
continuation:
honor society, according to an email sent out by the universitys student newspaper, The Daily Pennsylvanian.
The cause of death is still under investigation and no suspects have been identified at this time, but police are not looking for anyone else in connection with the case.
Carpenter was last seen around 2:30 a.m. Monday when she left her room to go to the bathroom. Her roommate reported her missing after she didnt come back home from the bathroom.
Her family has set up a GoFundMe page to help cover funeral costs. As of Tuesday afternoon, it had raised more than $5,000 of its $10,000 goal.
We are heartbroken over the loss of our beautiful daughter, sister, niece, cousin, friend, and all-around wonderful human being, Julia Carpenter, the family said in a statement on the GoFundMe page. She was loved by everyone who knew her and we ask that you please keep us in your thoughts and prayers during this difficult time. We will provide updates as they become available. Thank you for your continued love and support.
A candlelight vigil will be held at 6 p.

input: The Dow Jones today projected a 100-point gain in pre-market hours, as investors continue to assess the impact of growing trade tensions between the United States and China. This morning's rally comes after the Dow erased a 700-point loss during Wednesday
continuation:
s trading session. The S&P 500 is up 0.2% while the Nasdaq Composite is up 0.1%.

U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer said on Tuesday that he would meet with his Chinese counterpart, Vice Premier Liu He, this week in an effort to reach a trade deal by the end of the year. President Donald Trump has threatened to slap additional tariffs on $300 billion worth of Chinese goods if no progress is made in the talks. Investors have been concerned about the potential economic fallout from the escalating trade war between the two largest economies in the world.

input: CANBERRA, Australia -- A four-year search of the depths of the Indian Ocean has failed to find Malaysia Airlines Flight 370. But the unprecedented sonar hunt for the missing airliner might be close to solving 19th century mysteries - the locations of
continuation:
some of the world's most famous shipwrecks, including the Titanic and the RMS Lusitania.

The Australian Transport Safety Bureau (ATSB) said on Thursday it had detected a "possible signal" in the area where the plane disappeared in March 2014 with 239 people on board. It was not immediately clear what the signal was or how long it would take to analyze its data.

"This is the first time that we've been able to detect a potential signal from the bottom of the ocean," ATSB chief commissioner Greg Hood told reporters at a news conference in Canberra.

"We are hopeful that this will provide us with an indication as to whether or not there is something down there."

Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said he hoped the new findings would help solve the mystery of what happened to MH370.

"It is very difficult to understand why someone would do such a thing," Mahathir told reporters in Kuala Lumpur. "But I am sure they did it because they were disturbed by something."

He added: "I hope that we can find the truth and bring closure to the families who have lost their loved ones."

input: A police chase that began in Norwalk early this morning ended in Des Moines as the man being chased jumped to his death from a parking ramp. Norwalk Police Chief Eddie Kuhl says it began with a call of a person who was possibly suicidal who
continuation:
had barricaded himself inside an apartment building on the 200 block of North Main Street.
Start the conversation, or Read more at KCCI-TV Des Moines. Sign up for our daily newsletter and get breaking news alerts delivered to your email inbox every afternoon.
Kuhl says officers were able to make contact with the man around 2:30 a.m., but when they tried to arrest him, he took off running. The chase went through several Iowa cities before reaching Des Moines, where the man jumped out of the car and fell to the ground. He was taken into custody without further incident.
The mans name has not yet been released. The cause of death is under investigation by the Polk County Medical Examiners Office.

We need to get back to winning ways as quickly as possible. Weve got a lot of hard work ahead of us.
Ive had a good relationship with the fans and they know what Im trying to do here.

input:
When a South Carolina man found a Waffle House's only employee asleep, he decided to make the food himself.
Alex Bowen was returning from a night of drinking when he visited the restaurant to satisfy an early-morning food craving.
He waited
continuation:
in line for more than an hour before ordering his usual breakfast  waffles and hash browns.
Bowen told The Post and Courier that he didnt think anything of it at the time, but as he sat down at the table, he noticed one of the employees had fallen asleep on the counter.
I thought she was just sleeping or something, he said. I wasnt even thinking about her being drunk.
The next thing he knew, he heard someone calling him over. He looked up to see a woman who appeared to have been passed out on the floor.
She was laying there with her arms crossed, Bowen said. I was like, Oh my God, what happened? She was still breathing. I asked her if she was okay, and she said she was fine.
Bowen called 911 and began performing CPR until first responders arrived. The woman was taken to a nearby hospital, where she was pronounced dead.
Its a horrible tragedy, Charleston County Coroner Margaret Fisher said.
Fisher said the woman died of blunt force trauma to the head.

input:
The Senate is in a standoff regarding bills that would send relief funding to Puerto Rico, which is still recovering from Hurricane Maria.
On Monday (April 1), a measure was defeated in the Senate to provide disaster relief for Puerto Rico. Democrats voted against
continuation:
the bill because it did not include enough money for Puerto Ricos recovery efforts.
Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Kentucky) has said that he does not intend to bring the bill back up for a vote until the House of Representatives votes on its version of the relief package.
McConnell told reporters that the Senate will wait and see what happens with the House bill before deciding whether to move forward with their own legislation.
House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-California) has already announced that she plans to bring her bill to the floor later this week.
Puerto Rico Governor Ricardo Rossell has called for Congress to approve an additional $50 billion to help the island recover from the devastation caused by Hurricane Maria.
Rossell has also asked President Donald Trump to declare a national emergency so that more federal aid can be provided to Puerto Rico.

continuation:
while Glover, 31, was forced to withdraw from last years World Championships due to injury.
The pair won gold at London 2012 and Rio 2016 but missed out on selection for Tokyo 2020.
Glover said: Im just so happy to be able to do this. Its been a really tough year. I didnt know if I was going to make it back into the team.
Weve had a lot of ups and downs. Weve worked really hard to get back to where we are now.
Stanning added: Its been a rollercoaster of emotions. The last couple of years have been very challenging for me.
But Im so proud of my team-mates and everyone who has supported us through it.
Im just so grateful to be here.

input: Theres a new baby joining the Sister Wives family, as Robyn Brown is pregnant again. This will be Robyns second child with husband Kody Brown and her fifth in total. The new baby will be the 18
continuation:
th grandchild for the Brown family.

The news comes just days after it was revealed that Kody has filed for divorce from his wife of 22 years, Meri Brown. According to court documents obtained by E! News, the two have been separated for more than six months and are currently working on getting their marriage back on track.

After much prayer and consideration, I have made the difficult decision to end my marriage to Meri Brown, Kody said in a statement. I ask that you please respect our privacy at this time as we work through this together. We love each other very much and ask for your prayers during this time. Thank you for your support.

Meri also released a statement about the split, saying she was devastated by the news. She went on to say that they were still trying to work things out, but ultimately decided to call it quits due to irreconcilable differences.

We are heartbroken and devastated to announce that we are going our separate ways, Meri said. Its been an incredible journey and we are so proud of all that we have accomplished

Sharp saw sales drop 12 percent in the nine months to December as competition increased in the LCD panel and television markets, it said Wednesday.
The company saw demand for flat-screen TVs drop in markets outside of Japan and was also pinched by price
continuation:
cuts from Chinese rivals.
Sharps net loss widened to 2.1 billion yen ($18 million) from 1.6 billion yen a year earlier, while its operating profit shrank to 441 million yen from 515 million yen.
Sales fell 11.4 percent to 7.8 trillion yen ($71 billion), with Sharp blaming unfavourable market conditions in China, South Korea and Taiwan.
Sharp shares were down more than 6 percent in early trading on the Tokyo Stock Exchange before paring losses to be down 0.7 percent at 9,300 yen.
Sharp is struggling to turn around its business after a series of missteps over the past two years.
It has been forced to cut jobs, close factories and sell off assets in an effort to shore up its finances.
Last month, it said it had secured a $2.3 billion loan from a consortium led by Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group.
But analysts have warned that the company may not be able to raise enough money through debt or equity markets to stay afloat.
In October, Sharp slashed its full-year profit forecast, saying it expected to post a loss

Ptrick Kane and Corey Crawford have paved the way for Blackhawks championship.
It is amusing how people that normally could care less about hockey are now into it.
Something about winning and
continuation:
being a fan of a team that has won so much in the past few years makes me want to root for them. It's weird, but I can't explain it.
I think it's the fact that they've been on the losing end of so many close games that you're rooting for them to win because you know they'll be better next year.
That's exactly what I was thinking when I first started watching hockey. Now I just don't give a shit if we win or lose, as long as we make it to the Stanley Cup finals.
Same here.  I used to hate the Hawks because they always seemed to get away with things that other teams couldn't.  Now I'm glad they're doing well because I know they're going to be great next season.  I also like the fact that they seem to have a lot of young talent coming up through their system.  I'm excited to see them do well in the future.

input:
Before there was television, there was radio.
TV took radios shows, sponsors and many of its stars. It took the concept of networks, the 30-minute time slot and theme songs.
It duplicated most of radio
continuation:
s biggest hits, including The Star-Spangled Banner and God Bless America.
And it gave viewers a chance to see what their favorite entertainers were doing when they werent on TV.
In the early days of television, people had to wait for programs to be broadcast in order to watch them. That meant people had to stay up all night if they wanted to catch the latest episode of The Twilight Zone or The Dick Van Dyke Show.
But with radio, you could listen to any program at any time. You didnt have to worry about missing an important show because you were too tired to get out of bed in the middle of the night.
Here are 10 things you probably never knew about the history of radio.
1. The very first radio station in the U.S. was established in New York City on Dec. 12, 1877.
2. The first commercial radio station in the U.S. was owned by the National Association of Broadcasters (NAB) and began broadcasting on Jan. 1, 1927.
3. Radio is still used today in more than 200 countries.

They were once seen as the preserve of the geek, but nowadays personal opinion and diary pages - weblogs or "blogs" - are so powerful that huge corporations are taking an interest.
The sites that started as observational home pages for enthusiasts have become
continuation:
full-fledged publishing platforms with millions of visitors a month.
But what does it all mean? And how can you get in on the ground floor?
We've put together a guide to help you find your way through the world of blogs.
What is a blog?
A blog is a collection of short posts written by people who are interested in a particular topic. It's a place where people can share their thoughts and opinions about whatever they want.
You don't need to be a professional writer to start a blog. You just need to have something interesting to say.
How do you set up a blog?
There are many different ways to go about setting up a blog. The most important thing is to choose a domain name that reflects your business.
If you're selling products online, for example, then you'll probably want to use.com or.co.uk domains. If you're running a service, such as a web hosting company, you may want to use.net or.org.
Once you've chosen a domain name, you'll need to register it with the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN). This will cost between $50 (35) and $100 (

input: HOUSTON (CN)  A Mexican woman being held in a Houston immigration jail despite agreeing to return to the country she left with her parents as an infant won a small victory Monday when a federal judge said she should get a bond hearing to lobby for
continuation:
her release.

U.S. District Judge Lee Yeakel denied a request by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement to dismiss the case against Maria Elena Hernandez, who was taken into custody last year on charges of illegally re-entering the United States after leaving Mexico at age 2.

Hernandezs attorneys had argued that ICE has no authority to detain people who have not been convicted of a crime or committed any other illegal act.

The government has failed to establish a prima facie case that Ms. Hernandez is a flight risk or a danger to public safety, Yeakel wrote in his order denying the motion.

ICE spokesman Bryan Cox told Courthouse News that the agency will review the ruling before deciding whether to appeal.

We are reviewing the courts decision and considering our next steps, he said.

Hernandez arrived in the U.S. with her mother and stepfather from Chihuahua state in northern Mexico in 1997, according to court documents. The family lived in Brownsville, Texas, where Hernandez attended high school. She later moved to Corpus Christi, Texas, where she enrolled in a community

Speaking to reporters after their return from Colombo, Tharoor said that he had been impressed by the cordial relations between the Sri Lankan and Indian governments.

WASHINGTON (CNNMoney)  The White House initial proposal to avert the fiscal cliff includes $200 billion in economic boosters  a stimulus plan Republican critics are railing against when they say the country needs to start reducing debt.
But even deficit hawks say
continuation:
its too little, too late.

This is not going to get us out of this mess, Senate Budget Committee Chairman Kent Conrad, D-N.D., told CNNMoney on Wednesday. Weve got to do more.

Conrad and other Republicans have been pushing for years to cut spending and raise taxes on the wealthiest Americans as part of a balanced budget amendment to the U.S. Constitution.

But President Barack Obama has resisted such an amendment because he says it would take away the ability of future presidents to deal with the nations long-term fiscal problems.

The White Houses latest proposal, which was released Tuesday, does not include any cuts to entitlement programs like Medicare or Social Security. Instead, it calls for tax increases on the top 2% of earners and corporations.

Obama also wants to increase the retirement age from 65 to 67 for those earning more than $250,000 a year. He wants to raise the capital gains tax rate from 20% to 25%.

Its not clear how much revenue will be raised by these measures, but the White House estimates that raising the capital gains

input: Interior designer Abbe Fenimore knew that adding a kitchen island was one of the most important decisions shed make in remodeling her 1940s-era home in Dallas. A well-designed kitchen island can offer storage space, a work
continuation:
surface, and a place to prepare meals.

Fenimore, who is based in New York City, has designed kitchens for clients ranging from celebrities to Fortune 500 companies. Her clients have included Oprah Winfrey, Gwyneth Paltrow, George Clooney, and Tom Hanks. Im always looking for ways to make my clients lives easier, she says.

Fenimore wanted to create a space that would be inviting, functional, and comfortable for her clients. So when she saw an open kitchen island at a local furniture store, it seemed like the perfect solution. I loved the idea of having everything I needed right there in front of me, she says.

The Kitchen Island

The kitchen island is a versatile piece of furniture that can be used for many different purposes. It can serve as a work surface, a dining table, and even a coffee table. The design of the island also makes it easy to clean up after cooking. Its easy to wipe down with a damp cloth, Fenimore says. And you dont have to worry about spills or food getting on other surfaces.

input: Ethiopia says despite its trade relations with Somalias breakaway enclave of Somaliland, it does not support the sovereignty of the self-declared republic. Ethiopian foreign minister Seyoum Mesfin says Somaliland deserves to be
continuation:
recognized as an independent state.

Mesfin made the remarks during a meeting in Addis Ababa on Thursday with Somali President Mohamed Abdullahi Farmaajo.

Somaliland has been under international sanctions since 1991, when the Horn of Africa nation broke away from Somalia following a civil war that killed more than 100,000 people and displaced hundreds of thousands.

Getachew Reda, a spokesman for the president, told The Associated Press that the two leaders discussed the current political situation in the Horn of Africa region but did not give further details. He said they also agreed to work together to resolve the dispute between Eritrea and Ethiopia over the border between the two countries.

Eritrea and Ethiopia have been locked in a bitter dispute over the border since the early 1990s. A peace deal was signed in 2000, but both sides have accused each other of violating the terms of the agreement.

Archive/Manuscript  3 ms. boxes, 1 envelope.
Correspondence
continuation:
between the Czechoslovak Minister of Foreign Affairs and the Soviet Ambassador in Prague.
The correspondence consists of two letters from the Czechoslovak Minister of Foreign Affairs to the Soviet Ambassador in Prague. The first letter is dated March 16, 1948, and the second letter is dated April 15, 1948. Both letters concern the Czechoslovak-Soviet relations.
The correspondence also includes a memorandum written by the Czechoslovak Minister of Foreign Affairs to the Soviet Unions Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs on October 10, 1947, which concerns Czechoslovakias relations with the United States and the Soviet Union.

Attractive display of merchandise, like these antique bottles, attracts customers to your booth.
Every clothing store owner wants to see heavy traffic on the sales floor, but sales associates often need motivation to persuade the shopper to turn "I'm just looking
continuation:
" into "I want to buy."
The best way to do that is to show them something they've never seen before.
That's why it's so important to make sure you have a variety of products on display.
If you don't, you'll end up with empty shelves and people wandering around aimlessly trying to find what they're looking for.
So how do you create a display that will attract shoppers?
Here are some ideas:
1. Use a variety of colors.
Shoppers love to look at clothes in different shades of blue, red, or green.
But if you only have a few items in each color, they won't be able to tell the difference between them.
To get shoppers' attention, try using more than one color.
For example, you could have a light blue shirt and dark blue pants, or a light blue shirt and dark blue pants.
You can also use two or three different shades of the same color, such as a light blue shirt and dark blue jeans.
2. Have a lot of options.
It's not enough to just have one type of product on display.
Instead, you should have lots of options.

input:
Friday, the Fourth National Climate Assessment was released. Its a sobering look at the economic and physical effects of climate change in the United States, and where those changes are leading.
At 1,656 pages, the report is massive
continuation:
, but its not hard to get lost in it. Here are some key takeaways:
Climate Change Is Already Happening
Climate change is already affecting our lives in ways we didnt even know were possible.
The report found that extreme weather events like heat waves, droughts, floods, and wildfires have become more frequent, intense, and destructive over the last 50 years. These events cost us billions of dollars each year, and theyre getting worse.
For example, in 2018 alone, the U.S. spent about $7 billion on natural disasters, including hurricanes, wildfires, floods, and tornadoes. And that number is only expected to go up.
We can expect these costs to increase substantially as global temperatures continue to rise, said Michael Mann, a professor of atmospheric science at Penn State University, in an interview with The Washington Post. If we dont act now, were going to be paying for this for decades, if not centuries to come.
In other words, theres no time to waste when it comes to reducing greenhouse gas emissions.
Its a wake-

input:
Mr Clegg had done a Greta Garbo... I vant to be alone!
Anyone seen our Cleggy? Lib Dem MPs sat there looking faintly sorrowful, like children who had just booted their football over the garden fence. This was
continuation:
the moment when they realised that they were going to have to do something about their partys disastrous performance in last nights European Parliament elections.
The Liberal Democrats won only one seat in Scotland and lost all but two of its seats in England and Wales. That is not good news for Mr Clegg and his deputy Nick Clegg. It means that the party will have to work very hard to win back those voters who deserted it at the last election.
But what does this mean for Mr Clegg and Mr Cleggs future as Deputy Prime Minister and leader of the Liberal Democrats? The answer is simple: nothing. They are still safe from any immediate danger of losing their jobs.
In fact, they may even be able to count on the support of some of the other senior members of the Cabinet, such as Foreign Secretary William Hague and Home Secretary David Blunkett.
However, if Mr Clegg and Mr Cleggs party continue to lose votes in the next General Election, then they could well find themselves in a difficult position.
That is because, unlike the Labour Party under Jeremy Corbyn, the Liberal Democrats have never really been able to establish themselves as a mainstream political force in Britain

input: Infertility is one of the most difficult problems a couple can go through, and many people find discussing the issue with friends and family only makes things worse. A new study found that there are differences in the way men and women share information about their fertility
continuation:
struggles.

The study was conducted by researchers at the University of Southern California (USC) and published in the journal Social Psychological and Personality Science.

We wanted to see if we could get some insight into how men and women talk about infertility, said lead author Dr. Sarah Lai, an assistant professor in USCs Annenberg School for Communication and Journalism, in a press release. We were also interested in whether or not it might be possible to use this research to help couples who are struggling to conceive.

The researchers asked more than 1,000 participants to fill out a survey that included questions about how often they discussed fertility issues with friends and family, as well as how much they felt comfortable sharing these topics with others. The results showed that men and women had very different attitudes when it came to discussing fertility issues.

For example, while women were more likely to say that they shared their infertility struggles with close friends and family, men were less likely to do so. Men were also more likely to say that they did not want to discuss their fertility struggles with anyone other than their doctor.

Ford is accelerating the automotive design process with the Microsoft HoloLens virtual reality headset after a year-long pilot program.
Coming off a year-long pilot program, Microsoft and Ford have taken the wraps off a collaboration between the two companies that will help
continuation:
speed up the development of autonomous vehicles.
The partnership was announced on Tuesday at the Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in Las Vegas, where Ford unveiled its new Mustang Mach-E electric SUV. The company said it will use Microsofts Hololens technology to accelerate the development of self-driving cars by allowing engineers to work remotely from their homes.
Weve been working together for some time, but this is the first time were going to be able to bring our teams together in a way that allows us to really accelerate what we can do, Ford chief product officer Raj Nair told reporters at the CES press conference.
Nair added that the HoloLens would also allow the automaker to better understand how people are using the device.
If you think about the HoloLens, its not just a head-mounted display, its an augmented reality experience, Nair said. Its like having a second screen in front of your eyes. You can see things that arent there. You can see things that arent real. Its a very

This is our last day of discussing Betty Friedan's The Feminine Mystique. Join us at 3pm for a live chat and then follow along on Twitter using the hashtag #newmystique.
 Friedan is very interested in female
continuation:
sexuality, but she doesnt want to talk about it too much because it can be distracting. Instead, she wants to focus on how women are treated by menand what we can do about it.
 In her book, Friedan argues that women have always been oppressed by men, but theyve only recently become aware of their own oppression.
 Friedan believes that women need to take control of their lives, which is why she advocates for abortion rights.
 Friedan says that feminism is not a movement against men; rather, its a movement for women.

In this episode of the New York Times Book Review podcast, author and feminist activist Gloria Steinem sits down with editor-in-chief Margaret Atwood to discuss her latest novel, The Handmaids Tale.

The Handmaids Tale takes place in a dystopian future where the United States has declared war on Gilead, a totalitarian society ruled by an all-male ruling class. The story follows Offred (played by Elisabeth Moss), a young woman who becomes pregnant after being raped by Commander Waterford (Yvonne Strahovski).

What Happened in Cockpit of Flight 370?
Former accident investigator Steven Wallace speaks to circumstances if flight path was pre-programmed into the computer.
The pilot and first officer of the missing plane, both of them Malaysian, have come under
continuation:
intense scrutiny since their disappearance on March 8 with 239 passengers and crew on board from Kuala Lumpur bound for Beijing.
In an exclusive interview with Voice of America (VOA), former accident investigator Steven Wallace said that he believes it is possible that the pilots were deliberately diverted to avoid detection by radar.
Wallace, a retired U.S. Air Force colonel, has spent more than 30 years investigating air accidents around the world.
He told VOA: "I think it's very likely that they were programmed to go somewhere other than where they were supposed to be going."
"They could have been programmed to go over the southern Indian Ocean or off the coast of Africa," Wallace added.
Malaysian authorities believe that the Boeing 777-200ER crashed into the sea after running out of fuel in the early hours of March 8 while en route from Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) in Malaysia to Beijing Capital International Airport (BCIA).
Investigators are still trying to piece together what happened to the plane, which disappeared from radar screens at 1:40 a.m. local time (10:40 p.m. GMT) as it flew across the South China Sea toward the Strait of Malacca, one of the

input: Part Two: Last week I wrote about "Employee A," a prickly and counterproductive woman who was terminated by a female client of mine who had just purchased the company. Today we look at another employee that helped to create incivility in the
continuation:
workplace.

In my last post, I described how one of my clients, an executive recruiter, had been fired from her job because she had refused to work with a candidate who was black. In this case, though, it wasnt the candidates skin color that was the problem. It was the fact that the candidate was a woman.

Im not going to go into the details here, but suffice it to say that there are some things you can do to make sure that your employees dont act like jerks. One way is to be clear about what you expect from them. If you want good employees, you need to be clear about what you want out of them. And if you want good employees, you need to give them the tools they need to get the job done.

Here are a few tips for creating a positive work environment:

input: Ronald Clifton Longe Jr. and Jerome Duane Grant were married Saturday morning at Henrys restaurant in New York. Its owner, Henry Rinehart, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion
continuation:
, officiated.

She graduated from the U.S. Naval Academy in Annapolis, Md., where she earned a degree in political science. She served as an aide to Sen. John Kerry (D-Mass.) during his 2004 presidential campaign.

Mr. Grant is the son of the late Jerome Duane Grant Jr., who died in 2007. He was a member of the U.S. House of Representatives from New Yorks 21st congressional district.

Mr. Longe Jr. is a graduate of the U.S. Naval Academy. He served as a lieutenant commander in the U.S. Navy Reserve.

The groom-to-be is a graduate of the University of Virginia, where he earned a bachelors degree in international relations. He served as an officer in the U.S. Army Reserves.

He is a partner with the law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell LLP in Washington, D.C.

Smoking rates in US have fallen to all-time low, but how did they ever get so high?
(THE CONVERSATION) The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention calls cigarette smoking the leading cause of preventable disease and death
continuation:
in the United States. Smoking kills more than 480,000 Americans each year and is responsible for an estimated $200 billion in health care costs each year.
Cigarette smoking has declined dramatically since its peak in the 1960s and 1970s, when it accounted for about 40% of the U.S. adult population. It now accounts for less than 10% of the U.S. adult population.
But there are still a lot of people who smoke. According to the American Lung Association, more than 6 million adults in the U.S. smoke daily. And that number is expected to rise as more young people start using e-cigarettes.
Why does smoking remain such a big problem in the U.S.? A new study from researchers at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health provides some answers.
How did we get here?
The history of smoking in the U.S. can be traced back to the early 20th century, when tobacco was introduced into the country by immigrants from Eastern Europe. In the 1930s, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) began to crack down on the sale of cigarettes and other tobacco products. The FDA banned smoking in public places in

China pledges "notable" emissions cut but some find lack of firm number disappointing.
But the leader of the world's biggest emitter dashed hopes that he would unveil a hard target to kickstart stalled climate talks due to be reconvened in
continuation:
Glasgow later this year, saying it was too early to make such a commitment.
Chinese Premier Li Keqiang, speaking at the UN Climate Change Conference (COP25) in Madrid on Monday, said China would reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 and achieve carbon neutrality by 2060.
He did not give an exact figure or say how China would meet those targets, which are seen as crucial to keeping global temperature rises below 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels to avoid the worst impacts of climate change.
The pledge came after President Xi Jinping promised during his first summit with US President Joe Biden last month to do more to combat climate change than previous Chinese leaders had done.
"We will strive to achieve carbon neutrality by the end of the century," Li told the virtual meeting.
"We will also continue to take concrete actions to enhance the efficiency of our energy consumption and promote green growth."
Li also called for the international community to help developing countries adapt to the effects of climate change, including by providing them with financial support and technical assistance.
China is the world's top emitter of greenhouse gases, responsible for about a quarter of all global emissions, according to the International Energy Agency (IEA).

input:
Ex-chief of general staff among more than 100 former officers accused of overthrowing government in 1997.
A former Turkish army chief has gone on trial in Ankara along with more than 100 other suspects for allegedly plotting to overthrow the Turkish government 16 years ago
continuation:
, state-run Anadolu news agency reported on Wednesday.
The case is part of a wider investigation into alleged coup attempts against President Recep Tayyip Erdoan and his inner circle that have been under way since July 2016.
Former Chief of General Staff Necmettin Erbakan, who was sacked by Erdoan last year over allegations of corruption, went on trial on Tuesday alongside 94 others, including retired generals and admirals.
Erdoan accused Erbakan of being involved in a "coup plot" against him when he served as president from 2003 to 2014.
Erbakan has denied any wrongdoing and said the charges were politically motivated.
His trial comes at a time of heightened tensions between Turkey and the United States, its most important ally in the Middle East.
Ankara accuses Washington of supporting Kurdish militants in Syria's northeast, an allegation the US denies. The two countries are also at odds over Ankara's purchase of Russian S-400 missile defence systems.
On Tuesday, the US State Department said it was "deeply concerned" about the trial.
"We continue to strongly support the rule of law and respect for due process," the department said in a statement.

input:
Jan. 25 - A child is pulled from rubble in Aleppo while Syria's civil war foes held their first face-to-face meeting at the start of talks to end nearly three years of conflict. Mana Rabiee reports.
The Syrian opposition
continuation:
says it will not negotiate with President Bashar Assads regime until he gives up his nuclear weapons program, a demand that has been rejected by Russia as absurd and unrealistic.
The United Nations Security Council unanimously adopted a resolution last week calling for an immediate cease-fire and a political transition to end the violence in Syria.
But Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov said on Wednesday that the U.N.-led talks would be an exercise in futility unless there was a change in the Syrian governments attitude toward disarmament.
Lavrov told reporters after talks with his Turkish counterpart Mevlut Cavusoglu in Ankara: We have no illusions about the prospects for success of these negotiations.
He added: If we are going to achieve any results, then we need to get rid of this absurd idea that the regime should give up its nuclear program.
Russia and China have vetoed two previous attempts by the 15-member Security Council to impose sanctions on Syria over its use of chemical weapons.

input: Looks like Apple wants a slice of the wearable camera action, based on recently awarded patents. The US Patents and Trademarks Office today awarded the iPhone maker a series of 34 patents, including one that details a GoPro-like action camera system.
continuation:
The patent, titled Method and Apparatus for Providing Real-Time Video Recording, was granted to Apple back in January. It describes a system that would allow users to capture video with their iPhones or other mobile devices, and then send it to a computer via Wi-Fi or Bluetooth. That data is then analyzed by an app, which would be able to display the video in real-time, as well as provide information about the users surroundings.

This isnt the first time weve heard of Apple working on something like this. In fact, earlier this year we reported that the Cupertino-based tech giant was working on its own version of the GoPro Hero3+ camera. At the time, a source told 9to5Mac that the companys efforts were aimed at creating a more affordable version of the popular action camera, rather than a full-blown replacement.

In any case, its still unclear whether or not Apple will actually go through with its plans to create its own action camera. Well have to wait and see.

[USPTO via MacRumors]

THOUSAND OAKS, CA (RNN) - Less than two weeks after the Pittsburgh synagogue shooting that killed 11, another mass shooting has taken a dozen lives in California.
A gunman killed 12 people, including a sheriffs
continuation:
deputy, at a country music bar in Thousand Oaks on Wednesday night.
The suspect was identified as Ian David Long, a 56-year-old former Marine who had been fired from his job with the Ventura County Sheriffs Department.
He is accused of opening fire inside the Borderline Bar and Grill in Thousand Oaks at around 10:30 p.m. local time, killing 12 people and wounding several others before turning the gun on himself.
Thousand Oaks is located about 40 miles north of Los Angeles.
The victims have been identified by the Ventura County Medical Examiner-Coroners Office, which said they were between the ages of 18 and 60 years old.
Sheriff Geoff Dean told reporters he believed the shooter acted alone.
"We believe this to be an isolated incident," Dean said. "I don't think there's any threat to the general public."
President Donald Trump called the shooting horrific during a White House news conference Thursday morning.
"Our thoughts and prayers are with the victims and their families. We also want to extend our deepest sympathies to the law enforcement officers and first responders who responded so heroically last night," he said.
Trump said

as the man who saved Aleppo at a time when the city is on the verge of total collapse. But thats exactly what Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoan did in an interview with German magazine Der Spiegel published last week.
