input:
PULGA  In December 2012, a fierce winter storm toppled five steel towers that support the same PG&E transmission line that malfunctioned minutes before the Camp Fire roared to life.
Six years later, the 115,000-volt Caribou
continuation:
-Palermo Line is still in disrepair.
PG&E has spent more than $2 billion on repairs and upgrades since then, but the companys board of directors recently approved a new plan to spend another $3.5 billion over the next 10 years.
The proposal, which was unanimously approved by PG&E shareholders at its annual meeting this week, calls for the company to spend an additional $4.6 billion on the project.
We need to do everything we can to protect our customers from catastrophic wildfires like the one we saw last year, said PG&E CEO Bill Johnson during his opening remarks at the shareholder meeting. Thats why we are investing billions of dollars in wildfire prevention and preparedness, as well as improving our ability to safely restore power when its needed.
PG&E has already spent about $2.7 billion on the project, according to a recent filing with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). The company expects to spend an additional $1.5 billion to $1.8 billion over the next three years.
Its going to be a long haul,

input: Aside from LGs crazily stunning OLED Canyon, the biggest smack-you-round-the-face televisual spectacle of the 2018 CES comes courtesy of Samsungs The Wall.
continuation:
Samsungs The Wall is a giant LED wall that will be installed in New Yorks Times Square this summer. Itll be able to display anything you can think of, and its going to cost around $1 billion.

This isnt the first time weve seen something like this. Back in 2013, Samsung showed off a similar concept at its Unpacked event, but this one has a few more bells and whistles.

For starters, itll be capable of displaying 360-degree videos. This means that you can watch your favourite TV show or movie from any angle you want.

Itll also have built-in Wi-Fi, so you can stream content from your phone or tablet without having to leave the room.

Of course, theres no word on exactly how many people are going to be able to get their hands on this thing, or when itll actually go up for sale.

Were not entirely sure what Samsungs trying to do with this thing, but its definitely an interesting idea. Let us know your thoughts in the comments

input:
You made the Forbes Africa 30 Under 30 2018 list. Would you consider that your greatest career accomplishment?
I must say I feel honoured to be listed as one of Forbes 30 Under 30. However, I believe its a call
continuation:
to action for all young people who are passionate about their work and want to make an impact on the world around them.
How did you get involved in entrepreneurship?
My journey into entrepreneurship began when I was just 13 years old. My parents encouraged me to start my own business because they saw how much I enjoyed working with my hands and making things happen. It was then that I decided to pursue a degree in Business Administration at Stellenbosch University (SU).
What do you think is the biggest challenge facing entrepreneurs today?
Entrepreneurship has always been challenging, but its become even more so in the last few years. Entrepreneurship requires a lot of hard work, dedication, and perseverance. You need to have a strong belief in what youre doing and not give up. If you dont put in the time and effort, you wont succeed.
What advice would you give to someone starting out in entrepreneurship?
Its important to have a clear vision of what you want to achieve. When you know exactly what you want to achieve, you can focus your efforts and energy on achieving that goal instead of worrying about everything else that could go wrong.

input:
Polands ruling conservative government has moved to reinstate supreme court judges it forcibly retired, acting on an injunction issued by Europes highest court.
On Wednesday the Law and Justice (PiS) party submitted the relevant legislation on
continuation:
judicial reform to the lower house of parliament, which is due to vote on it next week.
The European Court of Human Rights (ECHR) in Strasbourg ruled in October that Poland had violated the right to a fair trial by forcing the Supreme Court judges to retire without giving them a chance to defend their cases.
The ECHR ordered Poland to reinstate all the judges who had been forced to retire, but the PiS government refused to do so.
In a statement published on its website, the justice ministry said the bill would strengthen the independence of the judiciary and guarantee the rule of law.
It added: We are confident that this bill will be approved by the lower house of parliament as soon as possible.
The move comes amid growing concern about the independence of the Polish judiciary after the countrys Constitutional Tribunal ruled last month that the constitution should be amended to allow President Andrzej Duda to run for re-election in 2023.
Duda is currently barred from seeking a third consecutive term in office because of term limits.
Critics say the tribunals ruling could pave the way for the president to appoint his own successor, potentially undermining the

input: In the most Well, duh news youll read this week, Moto2 rider Romano Fenati got dumped by his current team and, most likely, the team he planned to run for in 2019 after grabbing another
continuation:
top-10 finish at last weekends Aragon Grand Prix.

Fenati was one of only two riders to score points in the first four races of the season, but has since dropped down to 14th in the championship standings. He had a crash in qualifying on Saturday that left him with a broken wrist, which forced him to miss Sundays race.

The Italian will be replaced by fellow Italian Luca Marini, who currently sits in 15th place in the championship standings. It remains to be seen how much of an impact the switch will have on the 22-year-old, but its safe to say hes not happy about it.

Im very disappointed because I really wanted to fight for the podium, Fenati said in a press release. Id like to thank my team for giving me the opportunity to ride for them. Id also like to thank the fans for their support.

Ive been working hard for the past three years to get to this point and now I want to keep going. I hope to be back racing soon.

input: FILM: CLERMONT-FERRAND SHORT FILMS. Join Rooftop Films at the Socrates Sculpture Garden to watch a collection of new short films. All films are selected from the 2011 Clermont-F
continuation:
errand International Short Film Festival, which took place in May and June of this year. The festival was organized by Cinmathque Franaise de lOuest (CFAO) with support from the French Ministry of Culture and Communication.

This event is free and open to the public. For more information, please visit www.rooftopfilms.com or call 514-898-7000.

Filmmakers will be on hand to answer questions about their work and discuss their process during a Q&A session following each film.

In addition to viewing the films, attendees will have the opportunity to purchase a limited number of tickets for future screenings. Tickets are $10 per person and can be purchased online at www.rooftopfilms.com/clermontferrand or at the door one hour prior to the start of the screening.

input: DOVER, Del. (AP)  Ryan Blaney kept the party rolling from his first win this season long enough to stimulate business at his favorite bar. He soaked in the celebration from his checkered flag on the roval at Charlotte.
continuation:
Blaneys No. 12 Team Penske Ford finished third Saturday night at Dover International Speedway, giving him a second consecutive top-three finish and extending his winning streak to eight races. It was the first time he had three top-10 finishes in a row since July 2015.

Weve been working hard all year and it feels good to get some momentum going, Blaney said. Im really proud of our team. I think weve done a great job. Weve had a lot of ups and downs throughout the year, but I feel like were getting closer and closer to being where we want to be.

input:
Security always comes down to securing applications.
The whole point of firewalls is to hide internally deployed network applicationsassumed to have exploitable vulnerabilities somewherefrom the outside world.
The main weakness of firewalls is that they are
continuation:
only as good as their weakest link, and this can be a problem if you dont know exactly where that weak link is.
This is why it is important for security teams to understand the attack surface of their applications, so they can take steps to protect them.
But how do you do this?
To find out, I spoke with two experts in application vulnerability management (AVM) about the best way to do this.
First, lets take a look at some of the most common ways attackers try to get into your network.
1. Remote Code Execution
Remote code execution (RCE) occurs when an attacker has physical access to your network.
In other words, a hacker can gain remote access to your network by simply connecting to your network from another computer or device on the internet.
Its easy to think of RCE as something that happens to other peoples computers, but its actually much more widespread than that.
In fact, according to the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), nearly half of all cyberattacks occur through RCE.
2. Exploitation of Vulnerabilities
Exploitation of vulnerabilities refers to

input: Attorney General William Barr's inclusion of the phrase does not exonerate in his summary on Sunday afternon of the Mueller report has become a much-needed security blanket for liberal journalists. For the past 24 hours, CNN analysts, commentators
continuation:
, and pundits have been trying to explain away Barrs statement by saying that it was a slip of the tongue.

CNN legal analyst Jeffrey Toobin told viewers that Barrs use of the phrase doesnt exonerate should be read as an admission that the special counsel found insufficient evidence to charge President Donald Trump with obstruction of justice.

The attorney general is admitting that he doesnt think theres enough evidence to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that the president obstructed justice, Toobin said. Thats a pretty big deal.

Toobin went on to say that Barrs comments were a sign that the Department of Justice will now move forward with its investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. presidential election and possible collusion between Trumps campaign and Russia.

I dont know what else he could have meant other than this: Were going to continue our investigation and were going to see if we can make any more indictments, Toobin said. And I think thats

input:
A public policy group says states should not rush into leasing existing road assets to the private sector.
In a report released Tuesday, March 24, the Philadelphia-based Pew Center on the States urged states considering public-private partnerships for infrastructure to exercise caution
continuation:
.
The report comes as state and local governments are struggling to balance their budgets amid the economic downturn caused by the coronavirus pandemic, which has shut down much of the U.S. economy.
Pew said it is concerned that some states may be rushing to privatize roads and bridges without fully understanding the risks involved in doing so.
"It's important to remember that these projects will take years to complete, and they will likely require significant investment over the next decade," the report said. "States must carefully weigh the potential benefits of PPPs against the long-term costs."
Public-private partnerships have been used in many parts of the world, including in the United Kingdom, Australia, New Zealand and Canada. In the U.S., the federal government owns more than 90% of the nation's highways, according to the American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials (AASHTO).
In Pennsylvania, Gov. Tom Wolf signed an executive order last month directing the state Department of Transportation to work with PennDOT and other state agencies to develop a plan to lease or sell state-owned roadways to private companies. The order also directed the department to seek proposals from private companies to build, operate

input: LOS ANGELES  The primary backer of an effort to get a ban on circumcision on the ballot in Santa Monica is abandoning her push, saying the proposed legislation had been misrepresented as an effort to impinge on religious freedom. A similar measure in San
continuation:
Diego was defeated last week.

The California Family Council, which has spent more than $1 million on the campaign, said Tuesday that it will no longer support Measure C, which would have prohibited doctors from performing circumcisions without parental consent.

Were disappointed, but we dont think its going to go anywhere, the groups executive director, Michael Rabinowitz, said in a telephone interview. This is not about religion. Its about protecting childrens health.

Mr. Rabinowitz said he did not know what motivated the change of heart. He declined to say how much money the council had spent on the campaign.

In a statement, Mr. Rabinowitz called the measure unnecessary and harmful.

Circumcision should be a personal decision between parents and their child, he said. Its not a medical procedure, and its not necessary for boys to grow up to be healthy men.

input: The Promise: Using the Apple device's built-in accelerometers, the Dynolicious application measures vehicle acceleration (0-60 mph, 1/4-mile trap speed and elapsed time, etc), and cornering and braking grip. With that
continuation:
information, the app can be used to simulate driving a real car.

The Reality: The app is not as accurate as you might think. For one thing, it doesn't take into account wind resistance or steering angle. It also doesn't account for the fact that most cars are equipped with electronic stability control (ESC) and traction control (TC). In other words, the Dynolicious app is more of a "feel" simulator than anything else.

Still, if you're looking for a fun way to learn about how your car handles on the road, this is a good place to start. If you want to get a better idea of what it's like to drive a real car, check out our list of the best driving simulators for iOS.

Dynolicious ($2.99) | App Store

input: ORLANDO -- Leading Republican presidential candidate Ben Carson believes that federal and state official overreacted in trying to save Terri Schiavo, a Florida woman who died in 2005 as her husband and family battled over whether to keep her alive despite her
continuation:
severe brain damage.

Carson made the comments during an interview with The Christian Broadcasting Network's "The 700 Club" on Friday.

Schiavo was placed on a ventilator when she was 18 months old after her parents took her off life support because they feared she would die without food or water. Her feeding tube was removed at age 24.

Her husband, George, had argued for years that he should have been allowed to make the final decision about keeping his wife alive. He died of a heart attack two years later.

Carson told host Pat Robertson: "I don't know what happened there. I'm not a lawyer, but it seems to me that if you're going to take someone off life support, you should be able to do that. You shouldn't have to go through all this legal stuff."

Robertson responded by saying, "You're not a lawyer?"

"No, I'm not," Carson said. "I'm just a regular guy."

He added: "There's no law that says you can't take your spouse off life support."

Carson also criticized President Barack Obama's health care law, saying it is "a disaster

input: Shopify (NYSE: SHOP) is the poster boy for growth stocks: Shares of the cloud-based e-commerce platform have returned a staggering 441% since listing in mid-2015. It's not easy to replicate
continuation:
that kind of success, but Shopify has managed to do it by focusing on its core business and investing heavily in product development and marketing.

That strategy paid off in spades last quarter, as Shopify saw revenue grow more than 100% year over year. The company also reported an adjusted earnings per share of $0.08, which was up from $0.03 in the same period a year ago. That beat analysts' expectations by a wide margin, and it's the first time Shopify has beaten estimates in three consecutive quarters.

Here are three reasons why investors should be excited about Shopify today.

Image source: Getty Images.

1. A strong balance sheet

Shopify has long been one of the most cash-generative companies in the world. In fact, it's one of the few public companies with a negative net cash position.

In other words, it doesn't need to borrow money or sell shares to fund its operations. As a result, it has plenty of cash on hand to keep paying out dividends, buy back stock, and invest in new products and services.

Shopify ended the third quarter with $3.2 billion in cash and marketable

input: At 29, Gretchen Daily is a rising star of population biology. She works at both UC-Berkeleys Energy and Resources Group and Stanford Universitys Center for Conservation Biology on a fellowship specifically created for her. Daily recently made
continuation:
headlines when she became the first woman to be elected president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS), a prestigious scientific organization that represents more than 100,000 scientists worldwide.

But before she could become a leader in science, she had to work hard to get where she is today. Daily was born with spina bifidaa birth defect in which the spinal cord does not develop properlyand spent much of her early life in and out of hospitals. Her family moved around a lot while she was growing up. I went from one foster home to another, she says. I never knew where I was going to be living next.

After high school, Daily enrolled in the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) and graduated with a degree in biochemistry. After graduation, she got a job as a research assistant at the National Institutes of Health (NIH) in Bethesda, Maryland. During this time, she also worked part-time at the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) in Boulder, Colorado, and interned at the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) in Washington, D.C.

Hamid Ismailovs EBRD Literature Prize-winning Uzbek novel puts Central Asian literature in focus.
On December 31, 1937, 20th-century Uzbekistans most popular novelist, Abdulla Qodir
continuation:
zhanov, was arrested by the Soviet secret police and sentenced to 15 years in a labor camp for subversion of the socialist system.
The following year, he published his first book, a collection of short stories entitled A Tale of Two Cities, which is still widely regarded as one of the countrys greatest works of fiction.
In the years that followed, he wrote several more novels, including The Night Watchman (1942) and The Last Days of the Great Patriotic War (1944), both of which have been translated into dozens of languages.
Abdulla Qodirzhanov died at the age of 80 on February 1, 2020. He was awarded the prestigious Hamid Ismailov Prize for Literature in 2018. The prize is given annually to an author from Central Asia who has written a work of outstanding literary merit.
Qodirzhanovs Tale of Two Cities is set in Tashkent, the capital of Uzbekistan. It tells the story of two young menone of whom is a member of the Communist Party and the other a member of the

input: THE economic plan being chartered during the ongoing 2017-2018 budget debate aims to stabilise the countrys finances, Deputy Prime Minister K Peter Turnquest said yesterday, as he underscored the continued need to reduce discretionary spending
continuation:
.

Turnquest was responding to a question from Opposition Leader Kamla Persad-Bissessar on whether there would be any cuts in government spending under his administration.

He said that while it is important to maintain fiscal prudence, it is also important to ensure that government expenditure does not exceed its revenue generation capacity.

We have to look at our discretionary spending and make sure that we are not overspending or underspending, he said.

Turnquest was responding to a question posed by Persad-Bissessar, who had asked if the government would consider cutting some of the $2.3 billion allocated for the National Insurance Scheme (NIS) and other social welfare programmes.

Persad-Bissessar pointed out that this years budget has allocated $1.7 billion more than what was spent last year.

Turnquest said that the government will have to look at how it can continue to provide social services.

I am very concerned about the NIS because I think it is one of the most important social programmes that we have in this country. We cannot afford to let it go down the drain

A GP clinic in Edinburgh which is changing to a telephone assessment system three days a week has warned its 6,000 patients they could be turned away.
The changes at the Links Medical Centre come into force on Wednesday, May 1.
A statement
continuation:
from NHS Lothian said: We have been working closely with our partners at the Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP) and we are confident that these changes will provide an improved service for both patients and staff.
Patients who do not wish to use the telephone service can still contact us by calling 0131 456 2222 or emailing enquiries@linksmedicalcentre.nhs.lothian.gov.uk.
However, some patients have expressed concern about the change.
One patient told the Evening News: "I'm very concerned about this. I've been seeing my GP for over 30 years and it's always been done face-to-face.
"It's a bit of a worry."
Another added: "I don't think it's a good idea to switch to telemedicine because there's no guarantee you'll get through to someone."
NHS Lothian chief executive officer David Macdonald said: "We know that many people rely on their GP practice as a first point of call when they need medical advice or treatment.
"We want to make sure that we are doing everything we can to help them continue to access

If you're a social media user,

police say it's important to be aware of what your posts can do to others.
The Lower Penn Township Police Department is asking for the public's help in identifying a man who robbed a convenience store at gunpoint earlier this month.
Police said the incident happened around 4:30 p.m. on July 7 at the Circle K located at 515 N. Main St.
The suspect entered the store and demanded money from the clerk. He then fled the scene with an undisclosed amount of cash.
The suspect was described as a black male between the ages of 20 and 25 years old, standing approximately 6 feet tall and weighing approximately 180 pounds. He has short black hair and brown eyes.
Anyone with information is asked to call police at (717) 569-4100 or submit an anonymous tip online at www.penncountycrimestoppers.com or by texting "PACC" plus your message to CRIMES (274637). Callers can remain anonymous and may be eligible for a reward up to $1,000.

Immensely wealthy and powerful men like Peter Thiel and Elon Musk want to live forever. But at what cost?
In a 2011 New Yorker profile, Peter Thiel, tech-philanthropist and billionaire, surmised that probably the
continuation:
most important thing we can do for humanity is to make sure theres enough money in the world for everyone to have a decent standard of living.
Thiel has since gone on to become one of the most influential figures in Silicon Valley. He co-founded Palantir Technologies, an artificial intelligence software company, which was acquired by Oracle in 2014 for $3.8 billion. In 2016, he founded The Founders Fund, a venture capital firm focused on early-stage technology companies.
He is also the founder and CEO of Paypal Holdings Inc., the online payments company.
Thiels philanthropic efforts include funding a number of high-profile initiatives, including OpenAI, a non-profit AI research group, and Open Society Foundations (OSF), a non-profit organization dedicated to promoting human rights and democracy around the world.
But as his wealth and influence grew, so did his concerns about the long-term health of the global economy.

Now that flood waters have begun to recede, Texas victims of Tropical Storm Harvey face another challenge: eviction notices. Even worse, some people are still on the hook for rent on apartments they cant live in.
Sheri Ilo
continuation:
, who lives in a Houston-area apartment with her husband and two young children, says shes owed more than $5,000 in back rent from her landlord.
Im not going to pay it, she told CNN affiliate KTRK. I just dont know what Im going to do. I dont know if were going to be able to make our mortgage payments.
Harvey, which made landfall as a Category 4 hurricane on August 25, has killed at least 68 people and caused an estimated $125 billion in damage. The storm is expected to bring up to 10 inches of rain to parts of the state over the next few days, according to the National Weather Service (NWS).
The NWS issued a flash flood watch for Harris County until 6 p.m. local time Sunday, warning residents to prepare for heavy rains and possible flooding in low-lying areas.
Houston Mayor Sylvester Turner has declared a state of emergency for the city, freeing up resources to help those affected by the storm. He said he was working with the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) to coordinate relief efforts

input:
The island lifestyle may have unknown benefits, as Hawaii residents are the only ones in the country with an average life expectancy of 81 years.
Experts recommend that adults get at least seven hours of sleep per night, but 44.7% of Hawaiians
continuation:
dont get enough, according to a 2016 report by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).
A new study published in the American Journal of Preventive Medicine suggests that getting eight hours of sleep each night could help protect against heart disease, stroke, diabetes, and other chronic diseases.
Researchers from Brigham and Womens Hospital in Boston analyzed data from more than 5,000 men and women who took part in the Health Professionals Follow-Up Study. The participants were asked about their sleep habits, including how often they fell asleep or woke up during the night, and how long it took them to get back into bed after waking up.
They also answered questions about whether they smoked, drank alcohol, or had high blood pressure, among other health conditions.
After adjusting for age, race, education level, body mass index (BMI), and other factors, researchers found that people who got eight hours of sleep each night were less likely to be diagnosed with heart disease, stroke, diabetes, and other chronic diseases.
Our findings suggest that a healthy sleep pattern can reduce the risk of developing cardiovascular disease, said senior author Dr. David L. Hamermesh,

input: Its no secret that ride-hailing company Uber has been concerned about its competitors in the race to build autonomous cars. But text messages released as part of Ubers ongoing litigation with Googles self-driving car project
continuation:
, Waymo, paint a different picture.

Waymo, which is owned by Google parent company Alphabet, sued Uber last year over allegations that it stole trade secrets related to autonomous vehicle technology from its former employee Anthony Levandowski, who went on to found his own self-driving startup, Otto.

In one of the most damning texts, Levandowski allegedly told an Uber executive that he had stolen everything I know about autonomous vehicles.

Khosrowshahi responded: Thats not good.

input:
An NYPD administrative judge and its firearms review panel criticized the conduct of three police officers involved in the 2012 shooting death of a Bronx 18-year-old, records obtained by the Daily News show.
The judge's decision involving Officer Richard Haste, who
continuation:
was charged with second-degree manslaughter last year for his role in the fatal shooting of Amadou Diallo, is the first time that the panel has publicly addressed the case.
Haste had been on desk duty when he fatally shot Diallo during a traffic stop on Dec. 21, 2012.
In a letter to Chief of Department Terence Monahan, Judge Robert Kugler wrote: "I am troubled by the manner in which this matter has been handled."
Kugler also questioned whether Haste should have been allowed to return to active duty after being suspended without pay for two months following his arrest.
"It would be difficult to find a more egregious example of an officer violating departmental rules and regulations than this incident," Kugler said.
Monahan did not immediately respond to a request for comment.
Haste's lawyer, Joseph DePascale, declined to comment.
DePascale told the Daily News earlier this month that he plans to appeal the administrative judge's decision.
"We are confident that we will prevail at the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court," he said.
A spokesman for the Civilian Complaint Review Board (CCRB), which investigates allegations of misconduct

input: BlackBerry Ltd. has signed a deal to acquire U.S. artificial intelligence and cybersecurity company Cylance for US$1.4 billion in cash. The Ontario-based company called Cylance a pioneer in applying artificial intelligence, algorithmic
continuation:
analysis and machine learning to security.

Cylances technology is used by companies such as Microsoft Corp., Amazon.com Inc. and Alphabet Inc.s Google to protect against cyberattacks. It was acquired by Blackberry last year for about $300 million.

We are excited to announce that we have reached an agreement with Cylance, which will allow us to accelerate our growth strategy and expand into new markets around the world, BlackBerry Chief Executive Officer John Chen said in a statement.

The deal is expected to close in the second half of this year, subject to customary closing conditions including regulatory approvals.

BlackBerry shares were down 1.6 per cent at $14.40 on the Toronto Stock Exchange in afternoon trading.

Story continues below advertisement

BlackBerry said it plans to use the funds from the sale to increase its investment in research and development, sales and marketing and general corporate purposes.

Chen took over as chief executive officer in May 2015 after co-founder Mike Lazaridis stepped down following a failed attempt to sell the company. He had been CEO since 2010 when he took over from former CEO Thorsten Heins, who resigned amid

input: MEDELLIN, Colombia  Chiles Palestino qualified for the third round of the Copa Libertadores on Tuesday after beating Colombian side Independiente Medellin on penalties to win the second leg of the second round at
continuation:
the Estadio Nacional.

The game ended 1-1 after 90 minutes and went into extra time, which was decided by a penalty shootout following a 0-0 draw after 120 minutes.

Chile took the lead in the 11th minute when Mauro Zarate scored his first goal for the Chilean national team from the penalty spot.

Colombia equalized three minutes later through Juan Cuadrado, but Pablo Piatti put Chile back in front just before halftime with a header from a corner kick.

In the second half, Chile had several chances to score more goals, but they were unable to find the back of the net.

Medellin goalkeeper Carlos Lampe made some good saves in the second half to keep the scoreline level, but it was not enough to advance to the next round.

Chile will now face Argentina in the third round of the tournament. The match will be played at the Monumental de Nueva Inglaterra in Buenos Aires, Argentina on Wednesday, January 10 at 7:30 p.m. ET.

input: There's a lot of confusion around cloud computing. What is it exactly? Who is it for? What can it do? Hardly surprising then that groups are springing up that claim to help people understand the concept, see beyond the hype and get
continuation:
their hands dirty.

One such group is the Cloud Computing Alliance (CCA), which was founded in January 2009 by several companies including Amazon Web Services (AWS), Rackspace and Microsoft. It aims to "bring together the worlds leading cloud service providers so they can share best practices and learn from each other," according to its mission statement.

The CCA is not a government agency, but rather an industry association. Its members include AWS, Rackspace, IBM, Cisco Systems, EMC, HPE, Juniper Networks, Novell, Oracle, Sun Microsystems, Symantec, VMware and VMWare, among others.

"We want to make sure we're all on the same page when it comes to understanding what cloud computing is and how it can benefit our customers," said Andy Bechtolsheimer, senior vice president of product marketing at AWS, in an e-mail interview with Computerworld. "We've been working closely with the CCA for some time, and we look forward to continuing to work with them."

Bechtolsheimer declined to comment on any specific projects or initiatives that the CCA might be involved in. However, he

For the longest time, AC1900 adapters were regulated to the PCIe interface due
continuation:
to their high bandwidth and low power consumption. However, as we've seen with the recent release of the Intel Core i7-8700K and AMD Ryzen 7 2700X processors, this isn't always the case.
With that in mind, TRENDnet has released an AC1900 wireless USB adapter that can be used with both Intel and AMD chipsets. It also supports 802.11ac Wi-Fi and Bluetooth 5.0.
TRENDnet TEW-809UB: What you need to know
The TEW-809UB is a dual-band (2.4GHz/5GHz) 802.11ac Wi-Fi/Bluetooth 5.0 device that comes with a USB Type-C port. This allows you to connect up to two devices at the same time via USB 3.1 Gen 2 Type-C ports.
There are two USB Type-A ports, one of which is dedicated to charging while the other is for data transfer. You'll find a microSD card slot on the back as well, so you can expand the storage capacity if needed. The TEW-809UB is compatible with Windows 10, Mac OS X, Android, iOS, and Linux operating systems.

input: press release: Father of newgrass and King of Telluride Sam Bush has long since established himself as roots royalty, revered for both his solo and sideman work, which includes time with Emmylou Harris, Lyle Lovett, and B

la Fleck & the Flecktones. Now, hes set to release his first full-length studio album in over a decade, titled Sam Bush.

It was produced by Grammy Award-winning producer John Congleton (Eric Clapton, Paul McCartney) and features contributions from some of the biggest names in country music, including Tim McGraw, Brad Paisley, Lee Ann Womack, Alison Krauss, Jason Isbell, and more. The title track will be available for pre-order starting today, while all other tracks will be available for download beginning tomorrow.

Im very excited about this record, said Sam Bush. Ive been writing songs for years now, and Ive never felt like I had anything to say that wasnt already being said somewhere else. This record represents me at my best, and I hope people enjoy it as much as I enjoyed making it.

s list of the best high schools in the United States.

Saratoga High School ranked 4th-best in California on Niche.coms list of the best high schools in the United States.

Niche, a website that ranks schools based on criteria such as test scores, graduation rates and extracurricular activities, released its list of the top 1,000 public high schools in the country this week. The rankings are based on data from the U.S. News & World Reports 2013-14 Best High Schools Rankings, which were released earlier this month.

In addition to being named one of the best high schools in the nation, Saratoga was also recognized for having the highest average ACT score of any school in the state.

I think its really cool, said senior Iris Lu, who is majoring in business administration with an emphasis in marketing. Its definitely a big accomplishment. Im very proud of my school. Weve been working hard all year to get where we are right now. It means a lot to me.

input:
Chattanooga instituted a similar program in 2006. That city has about 6,400 employees compared to Lexington's 6,000.
The director of risk management there told the council the program is saving the city about $5 million a year, making
continuation:
it one of the most cost-effective insurance programs in the country.
"We've been very pleased with the results," he said. "I think we're on the right track."
Councilman Jim Shuler, D-4th Ward, was the only council member to vote against the measure. He cited concerns that the city would have to pay more for workers' compensation coverage if the program were to be expanded.
Shuler also questioned whether the city would be able to maintain its current level of coverage if the program were to expand.
"What I'm worried about is what happens when you get to a point where you can't cover all your claims," he said. "You're going to have a lot of people who are going to lose their jobs because they're not covered."
City Manager Mark Bragg said the city would need to look at other options if it decided to go ahead with expanding the program.
"It's important to remember that this is a pilot project and we don't know exactly how it will work out," he said. "We want to make sure we're doing everything we can to keep our costs as low as possible while still being able to provide good benefits to our employees."

input:
Already making use of USB 3.1 on your PC? Take a look at Vantec's latest NexStar external storage device for SSDs and small HDDs.
As the flood gates open for USB 3.1 devices, the storage market

If you're looking for an external storage device that can be used with both USB 2.0 and 3.0 ports, then you'll definitely want to check out Vantec's NexStar line of drives. "We've been working closely with our customers to ensure they have the best experience possible when it comes to USB 3.1," said Vantec's vice president of product marketing, Chris Kresser. "With the introduction of the NexStar 5500, we're giving users the ability to enjoy faster transfer speeds than ever before."

input: Andy Eccleshalls Changing Times shows an actual walk back through time as one strolls down Main Street. Starting with the present day near the fountain, as you approach the water, you walk back through the decades with

a sense of how things have changed and how they will change in the future.

Eccleshall says that he wanted to do something different this year for his 50th birthday, so he started working on the project about three years ago. It took him six months to complete, but it was well worth the effort.

Im not sure I could have done it without all the help I got from friends and family, Eccleshall said. Its been a lot of work, but its been fun.

The idea came to Eccleshall while he was sitting at home one day. He was looking out the window when he saw people walking along the street.

I thought, Thatd be a cool thing to do, Eccleshall said. I didnt know what it would look like, but I had a vision in my head.

He began sketching out some ideas. Then he went online and found some old photographs of Main Street.

I looked at them and thought, This is pretty cool,

input:
How David Bowie helped my autistic son become himself.
When my son Benj was a small boy of 4 and 5 with virtually no original language and no ability or desire to play in conventional ways, he and I connected through music. I
continuation:
m not sure how it happened, but one day we were sitting on the couch watching TV together when I suddenly realized that he had a song stuck in his head  Space Oddity by The Who. It was the first time Id ever heard him sing anything other than gibberish.
I asked him if he knew what the song was about, and he looked at me blankly for a few seconds. Then he started singing the words, and I could see the lightbulb go off in his head. Oh, yeah! he said. Its about space!
Benj has always been fascinated by space. He loved Star Wars as a kid, and hes always been fascinated by the idea of going to another planet and exploring its mysteries. He loves science fiction movies like Star Trek, and hes always wanted to be an astronaut.
But he didnt have any interest in playing with toys or building things. He just wanted to sit quietly and listen to the radio.
Thats when I decided to try something different. I bought him a set of headphones and told him he could listen to whatever

input:
The most popular teething rings contain hormone-disrupting chemicals, a new study warns.
Endocrine-disrupting chemicals are banned from use in products for children.
However, no studies have ever tested plastic teethers for
continuation:
their potential to disrupt the endocrine system.
A team of researchers at the University of California, San Diego (UCSD) has now discovered that these chemical compounds can be absorbed through the skin and enter the body via the gastrointestinal tract.
They say this could lead to long-term health problems, such as increased risk of breast cancer.
Scroll down for video
A team of researchers at the University of California, San Diego (UCSD) has now discovered that these chemical compounds can be absorbed through the skin and enter the body via the gastrointestinal tract (stock image)
WHAT ARE ENDOMORPHINES? Endorphins are naturally occurring hormones produced by the brain and released into the bloodstream when an individual feels pleasure or pain. They are also known as 'feel-good' hormones because they help us feel good about ourselves and our lives. Endorphins play a key role in the regulation of many bodily functions, including mood, appetite, sleep, memory and learning. Endorphin levels are high during pregnancy and early childhood, but begin to decline rapidly after birth. Source: National Institute on Drug Abuse Advertisement
The study, published in the journal Environmental Health Perspectives, was led by UCSD School of Medicine

input: Winchendon is a small country town in northern Massachusetts, right on the border with New Hampshire. The local rustic landscapes lends to outdoor activities such as hiking, cycling, boating, fishing, swimming and other adventures at Lakes Monomonac
continuation:
and Monomond.

The town has a population of approximately 2,000 people. It was founded in 1636 by William Winchcombe, an English settler who came to the area looking for land to farm. Winchcombes son, also named William, took over the family business after his fathers death.

Today, Winchcombe Farms is one of the largest dairy farms in the United States, producing more than 100 million gallons of milk per year. The company also produces cheese, butter, ice cream, and yogurt.

In addition to its agricultural operations, Winchcombe Farms offers a wide range of recreational activities, including horseback riding, canoeing, kayaking, biking, golf, tennis, and swimming.

There are several wineries within walking distance of the Winchcombe Farm. One of the best places to enjoy wine tasting is at the Winchcombe Vineyard. This winery is located just a few minutes away from the Winchcombe Farm. You can find out more information about this winery on their website: http://www.winchcombevineyards.com/

input: The Chancellor has taken to the TV studios once ahead of what was intended to be the UKs final week inside the European Union. He needed up commenting on reports in several of this mornings papers that the Cabinet was preparing to oust
continuation:
Theresa May as Prime Minister and replace her with a new leader who would try to negotiate a better Brexit deal.

He said: I think it is very important that we are clear-eyed about the challenges facing our country over the next few weeks, but I also think it is important that we do not allow ourselves to get distracted by those distractions.

Mr Hammond added: We need to make sure that we are focused on the task at hand, which is to deliver a strong economic recovery from the effects of the global financial crisis.

His comments come just hours after The Times reported that Mrs May had been told by senior ministers that she could face a vote of no confidence if she does not agree to renegotiate the withdrawal agreement with Brussels.

Downing Street declined to comment on the story when contacted by the Press Association.

In his interview with Sky News Sophy Ridge on Sunday, Mr Hammond said he did not want to pre-empt the outcome of any vote of no confidence.

I dont think its appropriate for me to speculate on what might happen in the House of Commons. We will have to wait and see

This is the last of a series of essays on Adam Curtiss essay series All Watched Over by Machines of Loving Grace, which you can watch for free here. I previously wrote about the series here and here.
One of Curtis
continuation:
s central themes in this series is that we are all being watched over by an omnipotent, omniscient, omnibenevolent machine that has no interest in our happiness or well-being, but only in its own self-preservation. This machine, he writes, does not exist to make us happy; it exists to make sure that we dont kill each other.
Curtis goes on to describe how we are constantly being monitored by these machines through the use of surveillance cameras, facial recognition software, and other technologies. He argues that these technologies have become so ubiquitous that they have become part of our everyday lives.
In his latest book, The End of History and the Last Man: How the Digital Revolution Permanently Changes the Way We Live and Work, Curtis explores the implications of this new technology for society as a whole. In particular, he looks at the rise of artificial intelligence (AI) and how it will change the way we interact with one another in the future.
Here are some highlights from Curtiss discussion of AI.

input:
The real value of a companyhospitals includedis not only in money, but in social good.
Daily conversations in healthcare are increasingly dominated by money. Healthcare reform is relentlessly focused on cost cutting. Hospitals are frantically developing strategies to
continuation:
reduce costs and improve patient outcomes. But what about the people who work for these hospitals? How do they feel about their work? And how can we help them?
In his book, The Real Value of a Company: Why It Matters Who You Work For and Where You Work (Harvard Business Review Press, 2016), Harvard Business School professor Robert Cialdini argues that the true value of a company is not only in its financial performance, but also in its social impact. In other words, its more than just a business.
Cialdini defines a company as a collection of people with different skills and experiences working together to achieve a common goal. He goes on to say that a companys purpose is to make the world a better place. A companys mission should be at the core of every employees decision-making process. If you dont believe me, ask your CEO or COO if he or she would want to work for a company that doesnt have a mission.

input:
Lesley and John Brown with their daughter Louise, the world's first 'test tube baby'.
IT is an irony that the parents of Louise Brown, the worlds first test tube baby, would today be ineligible for
continuation:
a posthumous Nobel Peace Prize.
The Swedish Academy, which awards the prize, has decided not to award this years prize to the couple because they are no longer alive.
Their daughter Louise was conceived through in-vitro fertilisation (IVF) when she was just three months old.
Her mother, Lesley Brown, and her father, John Brown, died within weeks of each other in 2012.
They had been married for more than 30 years and had two children together.
Louise was born on December 1, 2000, at the University Hospital of South Wales in Cardiff.
She was the first child of Lesley and John, who met while both were students at the University of Edinburgh.
John Brown was a chemistry professor at the University of Edinburgh, while Lesley taught English literature at the University of St Andrews.
They married in 1979 and divorced in 1992.
In 2001, Louise was diagnosed with Down syndrome, a chromosomal condition that affects about one in every 10,000 live births in the UK.
It can cause intellectual disability, learning difficulties, heart problems and breathing difficulties.
Louise also suffered from a rare genetic disorder called Prader-Willi Syndrome,

input: In the corporate world, both the culture of the business and its response to the outside world define its ability to adapt and survive. This includes attitude to risk and innovation, approach to corporate social responsibility, team building, diversity and inclusion policies and its bribery
continuation:
and corruption prevention program.

Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) is a concept that has been around for more than 30 years. Its an umbrella term used to describe a wide range of activities undertaken by companies to help their employees and customers live better lives in developing countries. CSR initiatives can be as simple as donating money to local charities or as complex as setting up long-term partnerships with NGOs to work on issues such as poverty alleviation, water and sanitation, education, healthcare, and environmental conservation.

The United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) defines Corporate Social Responsibility as a set of actions aimed at improving the well-being of society and the environment while contributing to economic growth and job creation.

Its important to note that not all CSR programs are created equal. In fact, there is no one size fits all approach when it comes to CSR. The key is to find the right fit for your company.

Here are some of the things you need to consider before embarking on a corporate social responsibility program:

What type of program do you want to undertake?

Last week I posted with suggestions and resources for managing your email inbox. Todays post is also about productivity  its about to-do list applications. More to-do
continuation:
list apps are available than ever, but which ones should you use?
Im a big fan of Evernote. Its one of my go-to tools for keeping track of all sorts of tasks. Its easy to use, has lots of useful features, and is free.
But what if you dont want to pay for Evernote? You can still get a lot of value out of Evernote by using its built-in to-do list app, Remember the Milk.
Heres how it works: When you sign up for Remember the Milk (or any other service), youll be prompted to create a new account. This will give Remember the Milk access to your contacts, calendar, and other information.
When you create a new account, youll be asked to enter your email address and password. If you forget your password, you can reset it by clicking on the Forgot Password link at the bottom of the page.

input: "We implore you to exercise your oversight responsibilities to make improving conditions at immigration detention facilities a top priority for ICE and ensure the humane treatment of detainees in federal custody," said the letter spearheaded by Oregon Democratic Rep. Suzanne Bonamici and Texas Democratic
continuation:
Rep. Henry Cuellar.

The letter, which was signed by more than 100 members of Congress and advocacy groups including the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU), the National Immigration Law Center (NILC) and the Southern Poverty Law Center (SPLC), also called on the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) to "immediately end its practice of separating children from their parents at the U.S.-Mexico border."

ICE did not immediately respond to ABC News' request for comment.

Last week, President Donald Trump signed an executive order aimed at ending family separations at the southern border.

"This is a humanitarian crisis that has been going on for many, many years," Trump told reporters at the White House last week. "I think it's very important that we take care of our people."

In June, the ACLU filed a class-action lawsuit against the Trump administration seeking to reunite families separated as a result of the zero-tolerance policy.

On Tuesday, the ACLU released a new report detailing the number of children who have been separated from their parents since April.

According to the report, there are currently 2,342 children under the age of 5

input: The medical device space is a slow-moving behemoth bogged down by regulation and in need of disruptive ideas and design innovation. In recent years, we've seen a number of interesting ideas emerge in the space from designing handwashing to the ways that
continuation:
wearable devices can help patients manage chronic conditions like diabetes or high blood pressure.

But there's still plenty of room for improvement when it comes to making health care more affordable and accessible. A new report from McKinsey & Company looks at some of the biggest challenges facing the sector and offers some suggestions on how to tackle them.

The report, titled "Healthcare Innovation: The Next Frontier," focuses on five key areas where the industry needs to focus its efforts:

Improving patient experience

Increasing access to care

Reducing costs

Eliminating waste

Improving patient outcomes

"Innovation is not just about coming up with new products and services; it's also about changing the way people think about healthcare," said McKinsey Global Institute managing partner John Vellardita in a statement. "We are witnessing a paradigm shift in the healthcare industry, as consumers increasingly demand better value for their dollars."

McKinsey found that the average American spends nearly $3,000 per year on healthcare, which is far higher than any other developed country in the world. As a result, the U.S. healthcare system has become one of the most expensive in the world.

From Pennsylvania to Phuket, Iceland to Indonesia, the options are proliferating.
Eating in Paris once meant meat, cream and cheese. But not anymore. Just ask Portland resident Jennifer Willett, who visited Paris in September for a week
continuation:
-long vacation with her husband and two young daughters.
I had never been to Europe before, so I was very excited about it, she says. We were staying at a hotel on the Seine, which is right across the street from the Eiffel Tower, and we walked over there every day. We went to the Louvre, the Muse dOrsay and the Arc de Triomphe. It was such an amazing trip.
But when they arrived back in Portland, Willett found herself craving something different. She wanted to try some of the food shed seen while traveling.
I was looking for a new restaurant that wasnt too expensive, but also didnt have a lot of stuff on the menu that you couldnt find in the U.S. or other countries, she says.
Willett decided to go to one of her favorite restaurants in the city: La Boulangerie du Montmartre.
I love their croissants and their baguettes, Willett says. Its just a really nice place to eat

input: Northeast Maryland holds many attractions, and cultural opportunities for visitors and residents including the Aberdeen Proving Grounds, the National Aquarium of Baltimore, the Baltimore Inner Harbor and Camden Yards, the Bulle Rock Golf Course, and major medical centers and universities
continuation:
such as Johns Hopkins University.

The region is also home to the world-renowned Chesapeake Bay Bridge-Tunnel (CBT), which connects Washington, D.C., with Annapolis, MD. The CBT was completed in 1997 and has since become one of the most popular transportation links between the two cities.

In addition, the area has a rich history of military service, including World War II, Korea, Vietnam, Desert Storm, and Operation Enduring Freedom. In fact, more than half of the men who served in the U.S. Armed Forces during World War II were from the state of Maryland.

There are a number of historic sites that can be visited throughout the state, including Fort McHenry in Baltimore County, the National Museum of African American History and Culture at the Smithsonian Institutions National Museum of African American History and Culture in Washington, DC, and the National Museum of the American Indian in New York City.

Baltimore is the largest city in Maryland and the second-largest city in the United States. It has a population of over 1.5 million people, making it one of the most populous metropolitan areas in the country.

input:
Future historians will probably refer to the first quarter of the 21st century as the Bike Age. Bikes are everywhere  and theres no escaping them.
No one denies that theyre a good idea in terms of reducing pollution
continuation:
, improving air quality, and making cities more livable. But is it enough?
A new report from the American Public Transportation Association (APTA) says that bike-share programs have been shown to reduce car trips by an average of 2.5 miles per person per day. Thats a pretty big improvement, but APTA also points out that the number of bikes on the road is still far too low to make a real dent in traffic congestion.
The report was based on a survey of 1,000 Americans who use public transportation or bike to work. The respondents were split evenly between those who own cars and those who dont.
Of course, this isnt the first time weve heard reports like this. A few years back, a study from the University of California, Davis found that bike-sharing programs reduced car trips by about 3.7 miles per day. And a recent study from the National Bureau of Economic Research found that bike-sharing programs reduced car trips by about 4.6 miles per day.
But the new APTA report is the first to look at the effects of bike-sharing programs on peoples daily commutes. It found that bike-

input:
Chevrolet unveiled its new SS sedan, which it will race in NASCAR, at Daytona International Speedway on Saturday.
Chevrolet may have pulled out of NASCAR had the sanctioning body not agreed to redesign race cars and make them more relevant to
continuation:
todays drivers.
The car is based on the Camaro ZL1 1LE, but with a few changes. For one, it now has an all-wheel-drive system that replaces the rear-wheel-drive system used in previous versions of the car. It also has a different front splitter and a larger rear diffuser, as well as a revised rear spoiler.
Other than that, the car looks exactly the same. The only difference between the two is the paint job, which is black instead of red.
Chevrolet said the car will be available for pre-order this summer.

input:
Taxpayers are handing businesses 93bn a year  a transfer of more than 3,500 from each household in the UK.
The total emerges from the first comprehensive account of what Britons give away to companies in grants, subsidies and tax breaks
continuation:
.
It is based on data from HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC), the Government's revenue agency, which says it has been able to calculate the value of such transfers by taking into account the value of the goods and services they provide.
The figures show that in 2018-19, the average taxpayer handed over an extra 1,000 to their local business or charity.
This was on top of the 1,300 they gave to the NHS and other public sector organisations.
In contrast, the average taxpayer paid no income tax at all in 2018-19, according to the Office for National Statistics (ONS).
The ONS said this reflected the fact that many people did not have enough money to pay any tax at all.
However, there were signs that the trend was changing last year.
In 2017-18, the ONS found that the number of people paying no income tax had fallen to its lowest level since 2010-11.
The ONS said the fall was partly due to a rise in self-assessment tax returns, as well as changes to the tax reliefs available to pensioners.
But it added: "We do not expect these trends to continue indefinitely."

input:
A video from conservative activist James O'Keefe sparked this most recent effort to strip NPR of public funding.
Washington (CNN) -- The House of Representatives passed legislation Thursday that would bar federal funding for National Public Radio -- a longtime target of conservatives irritated
continuation:
by the news organization's coverage of President Donald Trump and his administration.
The bill, which now moves to the Senate, was introduced by Rep. Steve King, an Iowa Republican who has been one of the most vocal critics of NPR in Congress.
"NPR is no longer a neutral news source," he said during floor debate. "It's a propaganda arm of the Democratic Party. It's a left-wing media outlet."
The bill would prohibit the Department of Education from providing any grant or loan money to NPR or its parent company, American Public Media, if it receives more than $10 million in public funds.
King's bill would also bar the Department of Health and Human Services from providing any grant or loan money to NPR or its parent company, American Public Media, if it receives more than $10 million in public funds.
In a letter to House Speaker Paul Ryan, House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell earlier this month, King urged them to take action against NPR and APM.
"We are writing to urge your leadership to pass H.R. 788, the 'Public Broadcasting Act,' which would prohibit federal funding for NPR and APM," he wrote. "This legislation is necessary

input:
AN award-winning taxidermist from North Yorkshire is bringing a long-lost bird back from extinction  at least in model form.
The creations of Carl Church will be the centre of the Great Dodo Exhibition at Kendal Museum from July 4
continuation:
to 8.
Carl, who has been working on the project for more than two years, said: Im very excited about this exhibition. Its something Ive always wanted to do and now that its finally happening I cant wait to share it with everyone.
This is the first time Ive ever had a chance to work with an endangered species, so Im really looking forward to seeing how they turn out.
Dodos are one of the worlds most iconic birds, but their numbers have dropped dramatically over the last century due to hunting, habitat loss and climate change.
They were listed as vulnerable under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) in 2015.
In 2016, the UK government announced plans to protect the dodo by banning the importation of wild dodos into the country.
However, the ban was later overturned by the European Court of Human Rights, which ruled that CITES did not provide sufficient protection for the dodo.
Carls work will be displayed alongside some of his best-known models

input: DEEP in the dark depths of the ocean, there are dragons. These dragons are not fire-breathing reptiles but devilish-looking fish with monstrous jaws and terrifying teeth. And their fire is a beam of red light that shines from a
continuation:
single point on their heads.

These creatures have been known to devour human flesh, and theyve even been known to attack ships. So its no surprise that the U.S. Navy has developed an underwater drone that can be used to hunt them down. Its called the Underwater Predator (UP), and it was unveiled this week at the Naval Sea Systems Command (NAVSEA) annual conference in Newport, Rhode Island.

The idea for the UP was born out of the need to protect our nations shipping lanes. The U.S. Navy wants to use unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) for surveillance and reconnaissance purposes. In order to do so, however, they need to be able to detect and track enemy submarines and surface vessels.

To accomplish this task, the UP will be equipped with sensors and cameras that can see through the water as well as infrared and sonar capabilities. This will enable the drone to find its targets without having to rely on visual cues alone.

Its also worth noting that the U.S. Navy doesnt plan on using these drones for combat. Instead, they want

input:
An Arizona man on Monday sued the Archdiocese of Philadelphia, saying church officials allegedly protected a sexually abusive priest who he said molested him at his Northeast Philadelphia parish and caused him years of psychiatric problems.
Identified by his attorneys only as a
continuation:
John Doe in the lawsuit filed in U.S. District Court in Philadelphia, the plaintiff is seeking unspecified compensatory and punitive damages for emotional distress, medical expenses, lost wages and pain and suffering.
A spokesman for the archdiocese declined to comment on pending litigation.
The lawsuit alleges that the Rev. Thomas J. OMalley, now deceased, abused John Doe when he was a child in the late 1960s and early 1970s at St. Mary Magdalen Church, where OMalley served as pastor from 1969 until his retirement in 1992. The suit says the abuse took place at the churchs rectory, which was located across the street from the church.
OMalley, who died in 2005, was a member of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Allentown, Pa., at the time of the alleged abuse. He was ordained to the priesthood in 1965, according to court documents.
In a statement released Monday, Archbishop Charles Chaput of Allentown condemned the alleged abuse.
I am deeply saddened to learn of the allegations against Father OMalley, Chaput said. My heart goes out to this young man

input:
Can Grizzlies get city's trust back like Memphis basketball, football?
Memphis football and basketball have regained the city's trust. Can Grizzlies do the same?
Memphis athletic director Tom Bowen stood along the sideline at Liberty Bowl Memorial Stadium taking in
continuation:
his teams game against North Carolina State on Saturday.
He didnt need to look far to see what was happening around him.
The stands were filled with red-clad NCSU fans, many of whom were decked out in the schools blue and gold colors.
They cheered every time their team scored a touchdown. They chanted Grizzlies! Grizzlies! when Ja Morant hit a three-pointer for the first points of the second half.
And they booed every time the Wolfpack made a field goal.
It was a scene that had never been seen before.
I think its a testament to how much our fan base has grown over the past few years, Bowen said. Weve got a lot of young people who are really passionate about this program and want to be part of it. And I think were seeing some of that come to fruition.
Its a sentiment shared by Grizzlies coach Taylor Jenkins, who said hes noticed a change in the atmosphere around FedExForum since he took over the team last season.

input: In this screen grab from a Sept. 21, 2018, video provided to The Associated Press by Earthjustice, an environmental advocacy group, a turtle is plucked from gray muck along the Cape Fear River near the L.V. Sutton Plant near
continuation:
Fayetteville, N.C. (Earthjustice via AP)

FAYETTEVILLE, N.C. (AP)  A North Carolina environmental group is suing the state Department of Environment and Natural Resources for not doing enough to protect endangered sea turtles nesting on the banks of the Cape Fear River.

The lawsuit was filed Tuesday in Wake County Superior Court against DEQ Commissioner Mike Causey and other agency officials. It says the department has failed to take adequate measures to protect the endangered Kemps ridley sea turtles that nest along the rivers banks.

Kemps ridley sea turtles are listed as threatened under the U.S. Endangered Species Act.

DEQ spokesman Chris Whitmire said the agency has been actively working with stakeholders to address issues related to sea turtle conservation but declined further comment.

ADVERTISEMENT

The lawsuit asks the court to force DEQ to take additional steps to protect the sea turtles.

input: LONDON  Vodafone says any move by Britain to bar equipment made by China's Huawei from all parts of new 5G networks would cost it hundreds of millions of pounds and very significantly slow down the deployment of the new
continuation:
technology.

The telecoms giant said in a statement on Thursday that it was "deeply concerned" by reports that the U.K. government is considering banning Huawei from its 5G networks, which are expected to be rolled out across the country over the next few years.

Huawei has repeatedly denied allegations that its equipment could be used for spying by China's government or security services. The company also says it complies with all applicable laws and regulations wherever it operates.

Vodafone, which is part-owned by Hong Kong-based CK Hutchison Holdings Ltd., said that if the ban were to take effect, it would cost the company between $300 million and $500 million per year, depending on how long it took to replace existing equipment.

We believe this decision will have a significant negative impact on our ability to invest in 5G infrastructure, Vodafone CEO Vittorio Colao told reporters on a conference call.

He added: If we dont have access to the latest technology, we wont be able to deploy 5G as fast as we would like to. We will not be able to deliver the benefits of

input: When the Elsas and Supermen trick-or-treat their way to our doorsteps next week, some will be toting an orange box with the word UNICEF on it. Since 1950, four years after the organization was founded
continuation:
in New York City, the United Nations Childrens Fund (UNICEF) has helped millions of children in more than 190 countries around the world.

This year marks the 50th anniversary of UNICEFs founding, which is why we thought it would be a good time to look back at how far the organization has come since its humble beginnings.

In the early days, UNICEF relied heavily on donations from individuals and organizations like the Rockefeller Brothers Fund, the Ford Foundation, and the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation. These foundations were instrumental in helping the organization grow into what it is today.

Today, UNICEF receives more than $3 billion in annual funding from governments, corporations, foundations, and individual donors. This money helps fund programs such as polio eradication, immunization campaigns, and water and sanitation projects, among many others.

UNICEF also works closely with the U.S. Department of State to ensure that all children have access to quality education and health care. In fact, the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) provides nearly half of UNICEFs total budget.

input:
President Donald Trump is planning to return to Texas next month to raise money for his re-election campaign, according to people familiar with his plans.
Trump has scheduled fundraisers on April 10 in Houston and San Antonio, according to those sources. Asked
continuation:
about the presidents plans, White House press secretary Kayleigh McEnany said Tuesday that the president will be making a number of stops across the country in the coming weeks.
The events are expected to draw hundreds of donors, many of whom have already contributed to Trumps 2020 reelection campaign.
Trumps planned visits come as he faces criticism over his response to the coronavirus pandemic, which has killed more than 100,000 Americans and thrown millions out of work.
He is also facing an impeachment inquiry into whether he abused his office by pressuring Ukraine to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden, a leading Democratic presidential candidate, and his son Hunter, who served on the board of a Ukrainian energy company.
Trump has denied any wrongdoing and says he did nothing wrong. He has sought to shift the focus away from his administrations handling of the virus crisis and onto Democrats, claiming without evidence that they are trying to undo his election victory.
In March, Trump canceled a trip to Florida after the state banned gatherings of more than 250 people. He also postponed a rally in Tulsa, Okla., that was set to take place on June 20. The event was later resched

input:
It's been a hellish year for music. Rick Parfitt died the day before (December 24). So many legends have passed away this year  from David Bowie to Prince to Leonard Cohen to Glenn Frey.
When I was in school,
continuation:
it seemed like every week there was a new death of a rock star. Nowadays, it seems like we're getting one every other week. It's hard to keep track of all the people who've left us.
I'm not sure how long it will take me to catch up on all these deaths, but here are some of my favourites:
Rick Parfitt
The singer-songwriter and bassist, best known for his work with The Smiths, has died at the age of 61.
Parfitt had been battling cancer for several years. He is survived by his wife and children.
David Bowie
The legendary musician and actor died on January 10 after a battle with cancer. He was 69.
Bowie was a trailblazer in the music industry, and he paved the way for so many artists to come after him.
Glenn Frey
Frey, a founding member of the Eagles, was found dead in his Los Angeles home on February 1 at the age of 67.
His cause of death has yet to be determined.
Leonard Cohen

The Seattle area has a new biotechnology company -- and this one is going to try attacking cancer by examining antibodies instead of tumors.
Johnny Stine, founder and chief scientist of the new Spaltudaq Corp., said the approach, if it
continuation:
pans out, could be used for other diseases as well.
"We're looking at a broad range of diseases," he said. "It's not just cancer."
Spaltudaq's technology is based on the fact that cancer cells are made up of two different types of proteins: Tumor Necrosis Factor Alpha (TNF-alpha) and interleukin-1 beta (IL-1-beta).
Both proteins have been shown to play an important role in tumor development and metastasis.
But they can also cause inflammation, which can lead to tissue damage and even death.
In a study published last month in the journal Science Translational Medicine, researchers from the University of California, San Francisco, found that TNF-alpha and IL-1-beta were able to bind to a protein called CCR5.
CCR5 is a receptor on the surface of many immune cells that helps them recognize and destroy foreign invaders such as bacteria and viruses.
When CCR5 binds to TNF-alpha or IL-1-beta, the cell releases its own inflammatory cytokines, including interferon-gamma (IFN-gamma), which causes the immune system to overreact

input: Asked where they had their most memorable campus experiences, Dartmouth students polled back when I was an undergraduate most frequently identified the Hopkins Center for the Arts. It is certainly the site I would have identified if asked. I still recall, to take just one example
continuation:
, a performance of The Tempest in which the entire audience stood up and applauded at the end of the play.

But what about the other arts centers on campus? How often do you go to see plays or concerts there? And how many of them are worth seeing?

To find out, I went to Dartmouths student newspaper, The Dartmouth Daily News, last week to talk with some of the people who work in the various departments that make up the arts center. (I did not interview any faculty members.)

Heres what I learned:

Dartmouths theater department has produced more than 100 shows since it opened its doors in 2001.

Of those shows, more than half were produced by outside companies.

More than 80 percent of the shows that have been produced by outside companies have been world premieres.

Dartmouths theater department produces more than 50 shows each year.

Dartmouths theater department has produced more than 20 musicals.

Dartmouths theater department has produced more than 10 plays that have won awards from the National Endowment for the Arts.

input: On July 26, 2018, onboard USS Midway Museum in San Diego, California, Chief Warrant Officer Five (CWO5) Alicia Lawrence was introduced and welcomed as the senior warrant officer of the Navy (SWON). She assumed the prestigious title and
continuation:
will be the first woman to hold this position.

This is an incredible honor for me, said Lawrence. Ive always wanted to serve my country, but I never imagined that I would get to do it as a woman. Its a dream come true!

Lawrence was born and raised in New York City and graduated from the United States Naval Academy in Annapolis, Maryland. During her time at NAS Pensacola, she earned a Bachelor of Science degree in Aerospace Engineering and a Master of Science degree in Aeronautics and Astronautics from the U.S. Naval War College in Newport, Rhode Island. After graduation, Lawrence served as a flight test engineer on the F/A-18F Super Hornet and F/A-18E/F Super Hornet aircraft.

After completing her active duty service, Lawrence went on to earn a masters degree in aeronautical engineering from the University of South Carolina in Columbia, South Carolina. She then returned to NAS Pensacola, where she worked as a research engineer for the Naval Surface Warfare Center Aircraft Division. In 2013, she transferred to the Naval Air Systems Command (

input: Signs have gone up naming a section of a Los Angeles-area freeway as the President Barack H. Obama Highway, seen from Pasadena, Calif., Thursday, Dec. 20, 2018. The signs posted Thursday on State Route 134 apply to a stretch
continuation:
of the highway that runs along the border between Orange and Los Angeles counties. (AP Photo/Ringo H.W. Chiu)

LOS ANGELES (AP)  A stretch of a Southern California freeway has been renamed in honor of former President Barack Obama, who was born in Chicago but spent much of his adult life in Hawaii.

The signs posted Thursday on State Route 134 apply to a stretch of the highway that runs along the border between Orange and Los Angeles counties.

Obama was born in Honolulu on Aug. 4, 1961. He graduated from Occidental College with a bachelors degree in political science before going on to Harvard Law School where he earned his Juris Doctor. He served as a law clerk for U.S. Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall.

ADVERTISEMENT

Obama went into public service after leaving the White House in January 2017. He is now a professor at Columbia Universitys Mailman School of Public Health.

___

Associated Press writer John Antczak contributed to this report.

input:
Eden Hazard was facing an extended ban for kicking out at a ball boy after the Football Association charged him over his sending-off in Chelsea's Capital One Cup exit at Swansea.
Belgian playmaker Hazard was already set to serve an automatic three
continuation:
-match suspension, having been sent off in the 2-1 defeat at Stamford Bridge on Wednesday night.
The 27-year-old will now be suspended for Saturday's Premier League clash against Stoke City and next week's Champions League last-16 second leg at Atletico Madrid.
Hazard, who has scored five goals this season, received a straight red card for elbowing Swansea defender Ki Sung-yueng in the face during the first half of the 0-0 draw at the Liberty Stadium.
Swansea manager Carlos Carvalhal said: "I don't know what happened. I didn't see it.
"We are disappointed because we played very well and deserved to win the game.
"It is a big loss for us. We had a lot of chances to score but they were good saves from Thibaut Courtois."
Chelsea manager Antonio Conte told Sky Sports: "I think the referee made the right decision.
"In my opinion, he saw the incident clearly. He saw the contact between the player and the player's arm.
"I am not going to say anything more than that. I think the referee did a good job."
